  • Condoms are highly effective at reducing the incidence of lower genital tract infections, which can ascend and cause PID.

 

Option D. Female condoms protect against STDs and HIV:

 

  • Female condoms, like male condoms, provide effective protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) and HIV by acting as a barrier method.
  • They prevent the exchange of bodily fluids and are recommended as a safer alternative for women.
  • Unlike male condoms, female condoms cover a larger genital surface area, offering additional protection against STDs like HPV and HSV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • IUDs increase the risk of PID and Actinomycosis, particularly in the initial post-insertion period.
  • Condoms (both male and female) reduce the risk of STDs and PID by preventing the transmission of sexually transmitted pathogens.
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) do not protect against Candidiasis; rather, they may increase the risk of recurrent vulvovaginal candidiasis due to hormone-induced changes in vaginal flora.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with severe flank pain radiating to the groin. Urinalysis shows alkaline urine (pH 7.5) and crystals as shown in the image below. Which of the following organisms is most likely associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Klebsiella pneumoniae

 

  • Coffin lid crystals are associated with struvite (magnesium ammonium phosphate) stones, which form in alkaline urine.
  • These stones are commonly caused by urease-producing bacteria, including Klebsiella, Proteus, and Ureaplasma.
  • Urease hydrolyzes urea into ammonia, increasing urine pH and promoting struvite precipitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Escherichia coli: Incorrect. E. coli is not a urease producer and does not cause struvite stones.

 

Option C. Enterococcus faecalis: Incorrect. Enterococcus does not hydrolyze urea efficiently enough to form struvite stones.

 

Option D. Shigella dysenteriae: Incorrect. Shigella does not infect the urinary tract and is unrelated to kidney stones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Struvite stones (coffin lid crystals) form in alkaline urine and are associated with urease-producing bacteria such as Klebsiella and Proteus.

questions.text: A 72-year-old female is admitted to the hospital with complaints of vomiting and abdominal distention. A nasogastric (NG) tube is inserted to decompress the stomach. However, the patient remains conscious and alert during the procedure. What is the best position to place the patient in during the insertion of the NG tube?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sitting with neck flexion

 

  • The ideal position for inserting an NG tube in a conscious patient is sitting with neck flexion. 
  • Sitting allows for better alignment of the upper gastrointestinal tract, and neck flexion reduces the risk of accidental entry into the trachea by aligning the crico-pharynx with the NG tube. 
  • This position also enhances patient comfort and minimizes complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supine with neck flexion: While neck flexion is beneficial, the supine position can increase the risk of aspiration in conscious patients and makes the insertion more difficult due to poor anatomical alignment.

 

Option B. Supine with neck extension: Neck extension in the supine position increases the likelihood of the NG tube entering the trachea instead of the esophagus. This position is not ideal for NG tube insertion in conscious patients.

 

Option D. Sitting with neck extension: Although sitting is a better option than lying supine, neck extension may lead to misguidance of the tube into the trachea and increases the risk of faulty placement.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The best position for a conscious patient during NG tube insertion is sitting with neck flexion, as it facilitates proper alignment of the tube into the esophagus. Correct placement of the NG tube is confirmed by:
    • Auscultation of air injected into the stomach while listening at the epigastrium.
    • Aspiration of gastric contents.
    • X-ray of the chest and upper abdomen (gold standard).

questions.text:
A 78-year-old woman presents with:

 

  • Gradually worsening joint pain and stiffness in the right hip for 6 months.
  • Pain worsens with prolonged activity and weight-bearing.
  • Hypercholesterolemia (managed with atorvastatin).

 

Examination:

 

  • Reduced range of motion in the right hip.
  • Crepitus on passive hip movement.

 

Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoarthritis (OA)

 

  • This presentation is highly suggestive of osteoarthritis (OA), the most common joint disease, characterized by progressive degeneration of cartilage and subchondral bone.

 

Key Features of Osteoarthritis:

 

Gradual onset of joint pain and stiffness → Develops over months to years.


Worse with activity and weight-bearing → Pain improves with rest.
Crepitus on movement → Due to cartilage degeneration and bone friction.


Reduced range of motion → Due to joint space narrowing and osteophyte formation.

 

Risk factors:

 

  • Aging (most common).
  • Obesity (increases mechanical stress on joints).
  • Joint trauma or previous injury.
  • Metabolic factors (e.g., hypercholesterolemia has been linked to OA development).

 

Why the hip joint?

 

  • Hip osteoarthritis is common due to high weight-bearing stress.
  • Knees, hips, spine, and hands are the most frequently affected joints.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Ankylosing spondylitis: Presents in young men (< 40 years) with lower back stiffness, sacroiliitis, and morning stiffness that improves with activity. Hip involvement is rare early on.

 

Option C. Osteoporosis: Causes fragility fractures, not joint pain or crepitus. In fact, osteoporosis has been linked to a reduced risk of osteoarthritis.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis (RA): Presents with symmetrical, inflammatory polyarthritis, morning stiffness lasting >1 hour, and joint swelling. Hip involvement is rare in early RA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteoarthritis (OA) presents with progressive, activity-related joint pain, crepitus, and reduced range of motion. 
  • Hip OA is common in older adults and worsens with weight-bearing. Management includes weight loss, physiotherapy, NSAIDs, and joint replacement in severe cases.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male presents with:

 

  • Severe generalized joint pain and difficulty breathing for 2 hours
  • Back pain and breathlessness for 3 months

 

Investigations:

 

  • Haemoglobin: 12.2 g/dL 
  • Reticulocytes: 3.4% 
  • Peripheral blood smear: 

 

 

What is the most appropriate prophylactic management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydroxyurea

 

  • The patient's presentation of severe joint pain, difficulty breathing, back pain, and dyspnoea, along with the finding of sickle-shaped red blood cells on the peripheral blood smear, strongly suggests sickle cell anaemia with a vaso-occlusive crisis. Here's why hydroxyurea is the appropriate prophylactic treatment:
    • Sickle cell anaemia is a genetic disorder characterized by abnormal hemoglobin (HbS), which leads to the formation of sickle-shaped red blood cells. These cells can cause blockage of blood vessels during vaso-occlusive crises, leading to pain, organ damage, and complications such as splenomegaly, anaemia, and dyspnoea.
    • Hydroxyurea is used as a prophylactic treatment for sickle cell anaemia. It works by increasing the levels of hemoglobin F (HbF), which reduces the sickling of red blood cells and decreases the frequency of painful episodes and vaso-occlusive crises.
    • Hydroxyurea has been shown to reduce the frequency of acute crises and improve quality of life in patients with sickle cell disease.
  • For acute management during a vaso-occlusive crisis, treatment typically includes analgesia, hydration, oxygen, and sometimes blood transfusions if complications arise (e.g., neurological impairment).

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Aspirin: Aspirin is used for pain management in some conditions, but it is not a prophylactic treatment for sickle cell anaemia and can actually increase the risk of bleeding in these patients. It also does not address the underlying pathophysiology of sickle cell disease.

 

Option B. Desmopressin: Desmopressin is used in conditions like von Willebrand disease or mild hemophilia to increase von Willebrand factor and factor VIII levels, but it is not indicated for sickle cell anaemia.

 

Option C. Factor VIII concentrate: Factor VIII concentrate is used in hemophilia A to replace the deficient factor VIII, but it is not used in sickle cell anaemia, which is a disorder of hemoglobin, not a clotting factor deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sickle cell anaemia is a genetic blood disorder that causes sickling of red blood cells, leading to vaso-occlusive crises, pain, organ damage, and complications like splenomegaly and anaemia.
  • Hydroxyurea is the most effective prophylactic treatment for sickle cell anaemia. It works by increasing hemoglobin F (HbF) levels, which reduces sickling and the frequency of painful crises.
  • For acute vaso-occlusive crises, management includes analgesia, hydration, and blood transfusions if necessary.

questions.text:
Match the following viral infections (Column A) with their characteristic clinical features (Column B):

 

Column A (Infections):

  1. Coxsackievirus A
  2. Herpes Simplex Virus Type 1
  3. Epstein-Barr Virus
  4. Human Immunodeficiency Virus 

 

Column B (Clinical Features):

  1. Fever, sore throat, multiple vesicles on the oropharynx, especially soft palate and tonsillar pillars.
  2. Fever, painful cold sores or fever blisters around the mouth.
  3. Fever, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, and fatigue. No vesicular lesions.
  4. Fever, pharyngitis, diffuse maculopapular rash, generalized lymphadenopathy.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D

 

  • Coxsackievirus A (1-A): Causes herpangina, which presents with fever, sore throat, and vesicular lesions localized to the soft palate and tonsillar pillars.
  • Herpes Simplex Virus Type 1 (HSV-1) (2-B): Causes oral herpes, characterized by painful cold sores or fever blisters around the mouth rather than vesicular lesions inside the oropharynx.
  • Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) (3-C): Causes infectious mononucleosis, which presents with fever, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, and fatigue, but does not typically cause vesicular lesions.
  • Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) (4-D): Acute HIV infection can present with fever, pharyngitis, generalized lymphadenopathy, and a diffuse maculopapular rash, but it does not typically cause localized vesicular lesions in the oropharynx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxsackievirus A: Causes herpangina, presenting with fever, sore throat, and vesicular lesions on the soft palate and tonsillar pillars.

 

Herpes Simplex Virus Type 1 (HSV-1): Causes oral herpes, with painful cold sores or fever blisters around the mouth but not deep oropharyngeal vesicles.

 

Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV): Causes infectious mononucleosis, with fever, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, and fatigue but no vesicular lesions.

 

Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV): Presents with fever, pharyngitis, generalized lymphadenopathy, and diffuse maculopapular rash but not localized vesicular lesions.

questions.text:
Which of the following stains is most appropriate for identifying fungal structures in tissue samples?

 

  1. Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS) stain 
  2. Von Kossa stain 
  3. Mucicarmine stain 
  4. Gomori’s methenamine silver
  5. Giemsa stain
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4 and 5

 

  • Fungal infections are commonly identified using special stains that highlight the fungal cell wall or internal structures. 
  • The following stains are widely used in histopathology and microbiology for fungal identification:

 

1. Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS) stain

 

  • PAS stain reacts with polysaccharides in fungal cell walls, producing a magenta or bright pink color.
  • It is particularly useful for detecting fungi in tissue sections and is commonly used for Candida, Aspergillus, and Histoplasma species.

 

3. Mucicarmine stain

 

  • Mucicarmine stain is used to identify Cryptococcus neoformans, as it selectively stains the capsule of the yeast pink or red.
  • It is highly specific for Cryptococcus and is valuable in diagnosing cryptococcal infections, particularly in immunocompromised patients.

 

4. Gomori’s Methenamine Silver (GMS) stain

 

  • GMS stain is one of the most sensitive stains for detecting fungi.
  • It highlights fungal cell walls in black or dark brown against a green background.
  • It is commonly used for Pneumocystis jirovecii, Aspergillus, Candida, and Histoplasma species.

 

5. Giemsa stain

 

  • Giemsa stain is mainly used for blood and bone marrow smears, but it is also useful in identifying intracellular fungi like Histoplasma capsulatum.
  • It stains fungal nuclei blue and cytoplasm light blue, making it useful for detecting fungi in cytology and histopathology samples.

 

Other Option:

 

2. Von Kossa stain: The von Kossa stain is a histochemical stain used to detect calcium deposits, not fungi. It is primarily used in the study of bone, calcified tissues, and pathological mineralization, making it irrelevant for fungal detection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fungal infections are commonly identified using special stains like PAS, Mucicarmine, GMS, and Giemsa stains. 
  • PAS highlights fungal cell walls, Mucicarmine stains Cryptococcus capsules, GMS is highly sensitive for detecting fungi, and Giemsa is useful for intracellular fungi like Histoplasma. 
  • The von Kossa stain is not used for fungal identification as it detects calcium deposits.

questions.text: Identify the device shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lister’s urethral dilator

 

The image depicts Lister’s urethral dilator: 

 

  • Used for urethral strictures
  • A metallic instrument designed to dilate narrowed urethral segments
  • Not used for drainage

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fistula probe:

 

  • Used for identify and delineating anal fistula tract during fistula surgery.

 

 

Option B. Malecot’s catheter: 

 

  • Used for suprapubic cystostomy or nephrostomy drainage
  • Has flower-petal-like wings that act as a self-retaining mechanism
  • Different from Foley’s catheter as it lacks an inflatable balloon

 

 

Option D. ICD tube: A chest tube (ICD tube) used for pleural drainage in conditions such as pneumothorax, hemothorax, and pleural effusion. It is a flexible plastic tube with multiple drainage holes and is placed in the pleural space to drain air or fluid. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A factory worker presents with chronic fatigue, wrist drop, and constipation. Examination reveals a bluish discoloration on his gums. Peripheral blood smear shows basophilic stippling of RBCs. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) EDTA

 

  • Lead poisoning in adults is common in occupational settings (e.g., battery factories, paint exposure, welding).
  • Chronic exposure leads to peripheral neuropathy (wrist drop), anemia, and Burton’s line.
  • The chelating agent of choice is EDTA, which binds lead and enhances urinary excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deferoxamine: Deferoxamine is used for iron toxicity, not lead poisoning.

 

Option B. Penicillamine: Penicillamine is used for Wilson’s disease (copper toxicity), not lead toxicity.

 

Option D. Activated charcoal: Activated charcoal does not bind lead and is ineffective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead Poisoning

choices.text: Repeat CXR in lateral decubitus position

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a history of congestive heart failure (CHF) presents with progressive dyspnea and orthopnea. A chest X-ray (CXR) in the posterior-anterior (PA) view shows blunting of the right costophrenic angle, but no fluid layering is visible. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the presence of a small pleural effusion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bedside lung ultrasound

 

  • USG is the most sensitive investigation for pleural effusion.
  • A lateral decubitus X-ray is the most sensitive plain radiographic technique for detecting small pleural effusions and can detect as little as 25 mL of fluid.
  • In contrast, an upright PA view requires at least 175 mL of pleural fluid to detect blunting of the costophrenic angle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat CXR in lateral decubitus position: Incorrect. This traditional method can help visualize small effusions better than a standard PA view by allowing fluid to layer out; however, it is less sensitive and specific compared to ultrasound.

 

Option B. High-resolution chest CT: Incorrect. CT is very sensitive but is not the first-line imaging for small pleural effusions.

 

Option C. Thoracentesis: Incorrect. Not indicated unless the effusion is confirmed and symptomatic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • USG is the most sensitive investigation for detecting small pleural effusions, identifying as little as 5-10 mL of fluid.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with locally advanced cervical cancer (FIGO Stage IIB) is planned for definitive chemoradiation therapy. The oncologist explains that concurrent chemotherapy enhances the effectiveness of radiation therapy (radiation sensitization) and improves overall survival rates. Which of the following is the most commonly used radiation sensitizer for the treatment of cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cisplatin

 

  • Cisplatin is the most commonly used radiation sensitizer in cervical cancer treatment.
  • Concurrent chemoradiation with cisplatin-based regimens significantly improves overall survival and disease-free survival.
  • Cisplatin enhances the effects of radiation by interfering with DNA repair, leading to increased tumor cell kill.
  • It is the standard treatment in locally advanced cervical cancer (Stages IB2–IVA).

 

Chemotherapy in Cervical Cancer Management:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paclitaxel: Used in metastatic cervical cancer, but not as a primary radiation sensitizer.

 

Option C. Carboplatin: Alternative for cisplatin-ineligible patients but less effective as a radiation sensitizer.

 

Option D. Fluorouracil - 5-FU: Occasionally used with cisplatin in chemoradiation, but cisplatin alone remains the preferred agent.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) is started on a new medication that reduces renal glucose reabsorption and increases glucosuria. Two months later, she presents with vaginal itching, dysuria, and malodorous urine. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Canagliflozin

 

  • Canagliflozin is an SGLT-2 inhibitor that lowers blood glucose by blocking glucose reabsorption in the proximal tubule, causing glucosuria.
  • Glucosuria creates an ideal environment for fungal and bacterial growth, leading to an increased risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs) and genital mycotic infections (e.g., vulvovaginal candidiasis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sitagliptin: DPP-4 inhibitor, increases endogenous GLP-1, but does not cause glucosuria or UTIs.

 

Option B. Exenatide: GLP-1 receptor agonist, promotes insulin release but does not affect glucose excretion in urine.

 

Option D. Glimepiride: Sulfonylurea, increases insulin secretion, but does not affect renal glucose handling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • SGLT-2 inhibitors (e.g., canagliflozin) lower blood glucose by increasing renal glucose excretion but increase the risk of urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to persistent glucosuria.

questions.text: What structure does the umbilical vein form after birth?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ligamentum teres

 

  • The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.
  • After birth, it functionally closes and forms the ligamentum teres (round ligament of the liver), which is found in the free edge of the falciform ligament.

 

Fetal Vascular Remnants and Their Adult Structures:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Umbilical ligaments:Incorrect – The umbilical arteries form the medial umbilical ligaments, NOT the umbilical vein.

 

Option C. Ligamentum venosum: Incorrect – The ductus venosus (NOT the umbilical vein) forms the ligamentum venosum.

 

Option D. Falciform ligament: Incorrect – The falciform ligament is a peritoneal fold that connects the liver to the anterior abdominal wall, but it is not derived from the umbilical vein.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is started on a diuretic for hypertension. Several weeks later, she presents with fatigue, muscle cramps, and hypercalcemia. Which of the following diuretics is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydrochlorothiazide

 

  • Thiazide diuretics (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide, chlorthalidone, indapamide) block the Na+/Cl− cotransporter in the distal convoluted tubule, leading to:

    • Na+ and water loss (diuretic effect)
    • Hypokalemia
    • Increased calcium reabsorption → hypercalcemia

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: False, Causes hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia.

 

Option C. Acetazolamide: False, inhibits carbonic anhydrase and causes metabolic acidosis, not hypercalcemia.

 

Option D. Mannitol: False, osmotic diuretic, does not affect calcium handling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thiazide diuretics (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide) cause hypercalcemia by increasing calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule.

 

Summary:

questions.text: Identify the image:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bier's block

 

Bier’s Block:

 

  • Bier’s block, also known as intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA), is a method used for providing anesthesia to the limbs. This technique involves:
    • Tourniquet application: A double cuff tourniquet is applied to the upper arm or thigh to occlude blood flow.
    • Local Anesthetic Injection: Once the blood is squeezed out from the arm (using elevation or Esmarch bandage), local anesthetic (commonly lidocaine) is injected intravenously into the limb.
    • Anesthesia: The anesthetic spreads through the veins, providing numbness in the area distal to the tourniquet. This technique is often used for minor surgical procedures or fracture reductions on the arm, wrist, hand, leg, ankle, or foot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radial Nerve Block: This is a nerve block technique that targets the radial nerve, commonly used for procedures involving the forearm, wrist, or hand. It does not involve a tourniquet or intravenous local anesthetic.

 

Option C. Median Nerve Block: This nerve block is aimed at the median nerve and is typically performed for hand or wrist surgeries. Again, it does not use a tourniquet and intravenous anesthetic.

 

Option D. Wrist Block: Wrist block involves blocking the nerves supplying the hand (radial, median, and ulnar nerves) at the level of the wrist. This is another localized anesthetic technique that does not use the double cuff tourniquet or intravenous injection as seen in Bier’s block.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bier’s block is an effective and quick technique for providing regional anesthesia to a limb by using a tourniquet and intravenous local anesthetic. 
  • It is typically used for short procedures involving the extremities.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents with complaints of persistent oral ulcers and a burning sensation in his mouth. On examination, there are white, non-scrapable patches on the tongue and inner cheek. The lesions appear firm and do not bleed when rubbed. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biopsy

 

  • White patches in the oral cavity that cannot be scraped off raise suspicion for leukoplakia, a premalignant lesion. 
  • Biopsy is essential to determine the presence of dysplasia or malignant transformation. 
  • It provides a definitive diagnosis and guides further management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antifungals: Antifungals are used to treat oral candidiasis, which typically presents as white plaques that can be scraped off, leaving an erythematous base. This clinical presentation does not match candidiasis.

 

Option C. Excision: Excision of the lesion is premature without a histological diagnosis. Biopsy must be performed first to confirm whether the lesion is benign, premalignant, or malignant.

 

Option D. Wide local excision: Wide local excision is indicated for confirmed malignancies or high-grade dysplasia. The current step is to obtain a biopsy to confirm the diagnosis before considering excision.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • In patients with persistent white patches in the oral cavity that cannot be scraped off, biopsy is the next step to evaluate for leukoplakia or malignancy. 
  • Early identification of dysplasia or carcinoma is crucial to ensure timely and appropriate treatment.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the infertility clinic after two years of unsuccessful attempts to conceive. Her menstrual cycles are regular, and she denies any history of pelvic infections or surgeries. The physician recommends a hysterosalpingography (HSG) to evaluate her fallopian tube patency and uterine cavity abnormalities. Which of the following is not an indication for hysterosalpingography (HSG)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vaginal bleeding

 

  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a fluoroscopic imaging procedure in which contrast dye is injected into the uterus to assess:
    • Tubal patency (for infertility evaluation).
    • Uterine cavity abnormalities (fibroids, polyps, Mullerian anomalies).
  • HSG is performed in the early follicular phase (Days 7-9) to minimize the risk of disrupting an early pregnancy.

 

Indications for HSG:

 

 

Vaginal bleeding (Option D) is NOT an indication for HSG.

 

  • Active vaginal bleeding suggests conditions like endometrial hyperplasia, malignancy, or acute infection, which are better evaluated using endometrial biopsy or hysteroscopy.

 

Contraindications for HSG:

 

  • Pregnancy
  • Acute pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
  • Active vaginal bleeding

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Reaction of nitric acid with amino acids in the skin
Deep tissue liquefactive necrosis by nitric acid
Deep tissue liquefactive necrosis by some alkali

questions.text: In a case involving suspected chemical exposure, an autopsy reveals extensive skin discoloration as shown in the image below. What can be the likely mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reaction of nitric acid with amino acids in the skin 

 

  • Nitric acid is a strong oxidizing agent and can react with amino acids. This reaction causes a yellow discoloration, called as xanthoproteic reaction (Xanthos means yellow). 
  • Yellowish discoloration of the skin and tissues, is a hallmark of exposure to this chemical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Deep tissue liquefactive necrosis by nitric acid: Nitric acid, being a strong acid, causes localized coagulative necrosis, rather than deep liquefactive necrosis.

 

Option C. Deep tissue liquefactive necrosis by some alkalis: Alkalis (such as sodium hydroxide or potassium hydroxide) can cause deep tissue liquefactive necrosis by breaking down proteins and fats in the tissues, leading to the formation of a liquid mass. However, the colour is not yellowish, it can be brownish. Also, in the image, only superficial burns are seen, not deep necrosis. 

 

Option D. Coagulative necrosis by carbolic acid: Carbolic acid (phenol) can cause coagulative necrosis, where tissue proteins denature and harden, forming a characteristic dry, leathery tissue. But it leads to a whitish or pale appearance, rather than a yellow discoloration. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Understand the chemical interaction between nitric acid and amino acids in the skin, which leads to a xanthoproteic reaction causing yellowish discoloration.

choices.text: The maximum milk output is seen at 12 months of lactation.
The coefficient of iron absorption in breast milk is approximately 70%.
Calcium absorption from human milk is superior to that from cow’s milk.
Human milk provides approximately 70 kcal per 100 mL.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is exclusively breastfed and has been growing well. A pediatrician educates the mother on the nutritional benefits of breast milk. Which of the following statements about breast milk is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The maximum milk output is seen at 12 months of lactation.

 

  • The maximum milk output is not observed at 12 months but rather around 6 months postpartum.
    • Peak milk production occurs at approximately 6 months, when exclusive breastfeeding is still recommended.
    • After 6 months, complementary feeding is introduced, leading to a gradual decline in milk production as the infant transitions to solid foods.
    • By 12 months, milk output is often significantly reduced, especially if breastfeeding is supplemented with other foods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The coefficient of iron absorption in breast milk is approximately 70%:

 

  • Although breast milk contains lower absolute amounts of iron than formula or cow’s milk, its absorption is highly efficient (about 70%).
  • In contrast, iron absorption from cow’s milk and formula is much lower (only 10–20%).
  • This efficiency is due to lactoferrin and other factors that enhance iron bioavailability, reducing the risk of iron deficiency anemia in exclusively breastfed infants.

 

Option C. Calcium absorption from human milk is superior to cow’s milk:

 

  • Human milk has a lower total calcium content than cow’s milk, but its bioavailability is much higher.
  • This is due to the optimal calcium-to-phosphorus ratio in breast milk, which promotes better absorption.
  • Cow’s milk contains excess phosphorus, which binds calcium and reduces its absorption efficiency.

 

Option D. Human milk provides approximately 70 kcal per 100 mL:

 

  • The energy content of breast milk is relatively stable around 65 Kcal/100ml
  • This energy comes from a well-balanced mix of lipids, carbohydrates, and proteins, ensuring proper growth and development in infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Breast milk is nutritionally superior to formula and cow’s milk due to its high bioavailability of nutrients, optimal macronutrient composition, and immune-protective factors. 
  • While iron content is lower, its absorption efficiency compensates for this. Milk output peaks at around 6 months, and energy content remains stable at 65 kcal per 100 mL.

questions.text:
Mr. Rajesh, a 61-year-old man from Chennai, presents with:

 

  • Fatigue, loss of appetite, and leg swelling for 1 month
  • Medical history: Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) on metformin
  • Blood Pressure (BP): 172/103 mmHg (Hypertension)
  • Examination:
    • Mild pallor
    • Pitting edema up to the knees

 

Investigations:

 

  • Serum urea: 44 mg/dL (Slightly elevated, normal: 7–20 mg/dL)
  • Serum creatinine: 1.45 mg/dL (Elevated, normal: 0.7–1.2 mg/dL)
  • Estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR): 58 mL/min/1.73 m² (Reduced, normal: >90 mL/min/1.73 m²)

 

Which is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypertension

 

  • This patient has chronic kidney disease (CKD), likely secondary to longstanding hypertension (hypertensive nephropathy), which is a leading cause of CKD in India.

 

Key Features Suggesting CKD:

 

Elevated serum creatinine and urea (indicating renal dysfunction)


Reduced eGFR (58 mL/min/1.73 m²) → CKD Stage 3a


Hypertension (BP 172/103 mmHg) → A cause and consequence of CKD


Edema (due to fluid retention and protein loss in urine)


Mild pallor (suggesting anemia of CKD, due to reduced erythropoietin production)

 

Hypertension as a Cause of CKD:

 

  • Chronic high BP damages renal blood vessels, leading to glomerulosclerosis and progressive renal dysfunction.
  • Hypertensive nephropathy is one of the most common causes of CKD in India, second only to diabetic nephropathy.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Glomerulonephritis: Typically presents with hematuria, proteinuria, and RBC casts on urinalysis. More common in younger patients or post-infectious cases.

 

Option C. Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD): Usually presents with enlarged kidneys and flank pain, not just hypertension. Strong family history is a major clue (not mentioned here). Ultrasound would show multiple renal cysts.

 

Option D. Pyelonephritis: Presents with fever, dysuria, costovertebral angle tenderness (CVA pain). No fever or urinary symptoms in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypertension is a major cause of chronic kidney disease (CKD).
  • It presents with high BP, progressive renal dysfunction (elevated creatinine, reduced eGFR), and fluid retention (edema).
  • Longstanding hypertension leads to glomerulosclerosis, causing irreversible kidney damage.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of alcohol dependence presents to the emergency department with confusion, visual hallucinations, and severe tremors 48 hours after his last drink. His vital signs show tachycardia, hypertension, and fever. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intravenous lorazepam

 

  • The patient presents with confusion, visual hallucinations, severe tremors, autonomic instability (tachycardia, hypertension, fever), and onset 48 hours after stopping alcohol, which is highly suggestive of delirium tremens (DTs), a life-threatening form of alcohol withdrawal. 
  • Intravenous benzodiazepines (e.g., lorazepam, diazepam) are the first-line treatment to prevent complications such as seizures and cardiovascular collapse.

 

Why IV Lorazepam?

 

  • Rapid onset → Effective in controlling agitation and autonomic instability
  • Prevents seizures → Reduces the risk of alcohol withdrawal seizures
  • Less hepatic metabolism → Preferred in patients with liver dysfunction

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haloperidol: Antipsychotics like haloperidol may worsen withdrawal symptoms, increase seizure risk, and do not treat the underlying cause of DTs.

 

Option C. Risperidone: Atypical antipsychotics do not prevent seizures and are not effective for alcohol withdrawal management.

 

Option D. Supportive care only: Supportive care (IV fluids, thiamine, electrolytes) is essential but not sufficient. Benzodiazepines are the cornerstone of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Delirium Tremens (DTs) (alcohol withdrawal delirium) is a medical emergency and if untreated the mortality rate is around 20%.
  • The symptoms and signs include disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucination (most commonly visual), coarse tremors, and autonomic hyperactivity.
  • It usually occurs after 48-72 hours of the last alcohol intake or reduction in the amount of alcohol use.

choices.text: Presence of neovascularization of the iris
Trabecular meshwork obstruction by retinal photoreceptor cells
Secondary angle-closure mechanism due to lens dislocation

questions.text: What characteristic feature differentiates Schwartz’s syndrome from other secondary glaucomas?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trabecular meshwork obstruction by retinal photoreceptor cells

 

  • Schwartz’s syndrome is characterized by trabecular meshwork obstruction due to free-floating retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells and photoreceptors, leading to secondary open-angle glaucoma. 
  • Unlike neovascular glaucoma, iris neovascularization is absent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of neovascularization of the iris: Incorrect. Unlike neovascular glaucoma, Schwartz’s syndrome does not involve neovascularization.

 

Option C. Secondary angle-closure mechanism due to lens dislocation: Incorrect. Lens dislocation causes mechanical pupillary block, which is not seen in Schwartz’s syndrome.

 

Option D. Chronic optic nerve head cupping: Incorrect. Schwartz’s syndrome is acute, whereas optic nerve head cupping occurs in chronic glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Schwartz’s syndrome is distinguished by trabecular meshwork obstruction from retinal pigment epithelial cells and photoreceptors. 
  • It is an open-angle secondary glaucoma and lacks iris neovascularization, differentiating it from neovascular glaucoma.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman presents with sudden, crushing chest pain radiating to her left jaw. Her father had a coronary artery bypass graft two months ago.


Investigations reveal:

 

  • Troponin: Elevated
  • ECG: shown below. 

 

 

Which is the most likely coronary artery affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Right coronary artery

 

  • ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF indicates an inferior wall myocardial infarction (STEMI).
  • The right coronary artery (RCA) is the most commonly affected vessel in inferior STEMI as it supplies the inferior portion of the heart, including the right ventricle and sinoatrial (SA) node in most people.
  • Elevated troponins confirm myocardial injury, and the classic presentation of crushing chest pain radiating to the jaw strongly suggests acute coronary syndrome (ACS).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left anterior descending artery (LAD): Typically causes anterior wall STEMI with ST elevation in leads V1-V6, I, and aVL, not in II, III, and aVF.

 

Option B. Left circumflex artery (LCX): Can cause lateral or posterior infarcts but usually does not produce isolated inferior lead ST elevation.

 

Option C. Left main stem: Affects both LAD and LCX territories, leading to extensive ST elevations across anterior, lateral, and inferior leads, often causing cardiogenic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Inferior STEMI (ST elevation in II, III, aVF) is most commonly due to right coronary artery (RCA) occlusion.
  • Anterior STEMI (V1-V6) is due to LAD occlusion.
  • Lateral STEMI (I, aVL, V5, V6) is due to LCX occlusion.
  • Extensive ST elevations across multiple leads suggest left main coronary artery involvement.

questions.text: Match the exanthematous diseases with their causative organisms:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-C, 2-B, 3-D, 4-A

 

  • Fifth disease (1-C): Also called erythema infectiosum, caused by Parvovirus B19.
  • Sixth disease (2-B): Also called roseola infantum, caused by HHV-6.
  • Scarlet fever (3-D): Caused by Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes).
  • Fourth disease (4-A): A historical exanthematous disease, likely caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A microbiology laboratory is testing the effectiveness of a sterilization method that involves DNA damage without raising temperature. The efficacy of this method is assessed using a standard biological indicator organism. Which of the following is the most appropriate test organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bacillus pumilus

 

  • Bacillus pumilus is the standard biological indicator used to assess the efficacy of ionizing radiation (gamma rays, X-rays).
  • It is a spore-forming bacterium, making it highly resistant, and thus a good test organism for sterilization validation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacillus stearothermophilus: Used to validate autoclave (steam sterilization) processes.

 

Option B. Clostridium sporogenes: Used for anaerobic sterilization validation.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Highly resistant to chemical disinfectants, but not used for sterilization testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bacillus pumilus is the test organism for validating ionizing radiation sterilization.

choices.text: It is the most commonly performed prenatal diagnostic procedure.
Chromosomal microarray can be performed on uncultured amniocytes
Blood-tinged amniotic fluid is seen in transplacental passage of the needle
Procedure related loss rate is 1 -2% when performed by an experienced provider.

questions.text: Which is incorrect regarding the procedure shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Procedure related loss rate is 1 -2% when performed by an experienced provider

 

  • Amniocentesis is the most commonly performed prenatal diagnostic procedure, done between 15-20 weeks gestation.
  • The actual pregnancy loss rate is 0.1–0.3% when performed by an experienced provider, not 1-2%, making option D incorrect.
  • Chromosomal microarray (CMA) can be performed on uncultured amniocytes, while karyotyping and FISH require cultured amniocytes.
  • If the needle passes through an anterior placenta, blood-tinged amniotic fluid may be aspirated.

 

Indications for Amniocentesis:

 

  • Diagnosis of fetal genetic disorders (e.g., trisomy 21, Turner syndrome)
  • Diagnosis of congenital infections (e.g., CMV, toxoplasmosis, rubella)
  • Evaluation of anemia in Rh alloimmunization (ΔOD450 in amniotic fluid)
  • Determination of fetal lung maturity (Lecithin/Sphingomyelin ratio, Phosphatidylglycerol test)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the most commonly performed prenatal diagnostic procedure: Correct – Amniocentesis is the most frequently used invasive prenatal test.

 

Option B. Chromosomal microarray can be performed on uncultured amniocytes: Correct – CMA detects microdeletions/duplications without requiring cell culture.

 

Option C. Blood-tinged amniotic fluid is seen in transplacental passage of the needle: Correct – When the placenta is anterior, blood-tinged amniotic fluid is more common.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Shaving with razor night before operation

questions.text: Which of the following is the best method for hair removal to avoid surgical site infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hair clippers on the table 

 

  • Using hair clippers immediately before surgery is the best method for hair removal as it minimizes skin trauma and bacterial colonization.
  • Clippers trim the hair without causing micro-abrasions, reducing the risk of infection compared to razors.
  • Performing the clipping just before surgery minimizes the time for bacteria to colonize the area.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shaving with a razor the night before the operation: Shaving with a razor creates micro-abrasions in the skin, which act as entry points for bacteria. When done the night before surgery, there is additional time for bacterial colonization, increasing the risk of surgical site infection.

 

Option B. Depilatory cream before the operation: Depilatory creams do not create abrasions like razors, but they can irritate the skin, leading to a weakened skin barrier. This irritation may increase the risk of infection, especially if not used correctly or if a patient has sensitive skin.

 

Option D. Not to shave: While avoiding hair removal entirely may seem safe, excessive hair at the surgical site can interfere with skin preparation, draping, and surgical access, potentially increasing the risk of infection.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The best method for hair removal to reduce the risk of surgical site infection is the use of hair clippers immediately before surgery, as this avoids skin trauma and limits bacterial colonization. 
  • Proper preoperative preparation is critical for preventing postoperative complications.

questions.text: A researcher is calculating the Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) for various nutrients in a population. While most nutrients have their RDA set by adding 2 standard deviations (SD) to the estimated average requirement (EAR), which of the following nutrients is an exception, where 2 SD is not added to determine its RDA?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Energy

 

  • The Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) is typically calculated as:

 

RDA = EAR + 2SD 

 

This ensures that the recommendation meets the needs of nearly all (97–98%) individuals in a given population.

 

  • However, energy (caloric intake) is an exception.
    • Instead of adding 2 SD, energy recommendations are based on the mean requirement because excessive caloric intake can lead to obesity and metabolic disorders.
    • The Estimated Energy Requirement (EER) is calculated based on age, gender, weight, height, and physical activity level rather than a statistical distribution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron: Iron has a highly skewed requirement distribution due to menstrual losses in females. RDA accounts for this by adding 2 SD to the EAR.

 

Option B. Calcium: Calcium RDA follows the typical formula of EAR + 2 SD to cover bone health and metabolic needs.

 

Option D. Vitamin A: The RDA for Vitamin A is set using EAR + 2 SD to prevent deficiency-related conditions like night blindness and xerophthalmia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The RDA for most nutrients is calculated as EAR + 2 SD, except for energy, which is based on the mean estimated energy requirement to avoid excessive caloric intake.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are correct, and Reason is the correct explanation.
Both Assertion and Reason are correct, but Reason is not the correct explanation.
Assertion is correct, but Reason is incorrect.
Assertion is incorrect, but Reason is correct.

questions.text:
Assertion: Malignant hyperthermia is a life-threatening condition triggered by volatile anesthetics and succinylcholine, leading to uncontrolled muscle contractions and hypermetabolism.

 

Reason: Malignant hyperthermia occurs due to impaired ATP production in mitochondria, leading to excessive heat generation and acidosis.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Assertion is correct, but Reason is incorrect.

 

  • Malignant hyperthermia is a pharmacogenetic disorder caused by a mutation in the RYR1 gene, which results in uncontrolled calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum after exposure to volatile anesthetics or succinylcholine.
  • This leads to sustained muscle contractions, excessive heat production, and metabolic acidosis, making it a medical emergency.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Malignant hyperthermia results from excessive calcium release due to RYR1 mutation, causing hypermetabolism, not mitochondrial ATP dysfunction.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman presents with:

 

  • Exertional shortness of breath and fatigue for the past year
  • Type 1 diabetes mellitus, managed with a basal-bolus insulin regimen, with a recent HbA1c of 46 mmol/mol
  • Red, swollen tongue and impaired vibration in the distal lower limbs

 

Investigations:

 

  • Haemoglobin: 79 g/L 
  • Mean cell volume (MCV): 113 fL 
  • Peripheral smear: 

 

 

Which of the following antibodies would be raised?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intrinsic factor antibodies

 

  • The patient's presentation of exertional shortness of breath, fatigue, macrocytic anaemia (indicated by the high MCV of 113 fL), red, swollen tongue (known as glossitis), and impaired vibration sensation in the legs strongly suggests pernicious anaemia, which is the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • Pernicious anaemia is an autoimmune condition that results from the loss of intrinsic factor, which is necessary for vitamin B12 absorption in the ileum. 
  • The immune system produces intrinsic factor antibodies that attack the intrinsic factor or the gastric parietal cells that produce it. 
  • The deficiency in vitamin B12 leads to macrocytic anaemia and neurological symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy (as seen in this patient with impaired vibration sensation).

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Antihistone antibodies: Antihistone antibodies are primarily associated with drug-induced lupus or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). These conditions do not typically present with the macrocytic anaemia and neurological signs seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Antimitochondrial antibodies: Antimitochondrial antibodies are associated with primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), a liver disease, not with the signs of B12 deficiency or pernicious anaemia.

 

Option C. Antitissue transglutaminase antibodies: Antitissue transglutaminase antibodies are associated with celiac disease, which could lead to malabsorption of vitamin B12, but this is not the most likely explanation for this patient's autoimmune history, pernicious anaemia, and macrocytic anaemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pernicious anaemia is a common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to macrocytic anaemia and neurological symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy.
  • The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of intrinsic factor antibodies, which are found in patients with autoimmune pernicious anaemia.
  • Management includes vitamin B12 replacement, typically via intramuscular injections or oral high-dose B12.

questions.text:
Match the hematopoietic growth factor with its corresponding clinical use: 

 

Column A (Drug):

  1. Filgrastim
  2. Eltrombopag
  3. Darbepoetin
  4. Oprelvekin

 

Column B (Clinical Use):

  1. Anemia associated with chronic kidney disease
  2. Thrombocytopenia associated with cancer chemotherapy
  3. Neutropenia associated with cancer chemotherapy
  4. Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B

 

1) Filgrastim (G-CSF) → C) Neutropenia associated with cancer chemotherapy

 

  • Filgrastim is a granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF).
  • It stimulates the proliferation and differentiation of neutrophils in the bone marrow, helping restore neutrophil counts in conditions of bone marrow suppression.
  • Indications:
    • Neutropenia induced by cancer chemotherapy (e.g., after myelosuppressive agents like cyclophosphamide or doxorubicin).
    • Bone marrow transplantation (reduces infection risk by promoting neutrophil recovery).
    • Severe congenital neutropenia (Kostmann syndrome).
  • Mechanism:
    • Binds to G-CSF receptors on hematopoietic stem cells, stimulating granulopoiesis (neutrophil production).

 

2) Eltrombopag → D) Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)

 

  • Eltrombopag is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist (TPO-RA).
  • It stimulates platelet production by binding to the thrombopoietin receptor on megakaryocytes.
  • Indications:
    • Primary treatment for refractory or chronic ITP (used when steroids or IVIG fail).
    • Aplastic anemia (when bone marrow fails to produce platelets and other blood cells).
    • Thrombocytopenia in hepatitis C-associated liver disease (to reduce bleeding risk before procedures).
  • Mechanism:
    • Mimics thrombopoietin, stimulating megakaryocytes in the bone marrow to increase platelet production.

 

3) Darbepoetin → A) Anemia associated with chronic kidney disease (CKD)

 

  • Darbepoetin is a recombinant erythropoietin (EPO) analog.
  • It stimulates red blood cell (RBC) production, mimicking natural erythropoietin.
  • Indications:
    • Anemia due to chronic kidney disease (CKD) (patients with ESRD lack endogenous erythropoietin).
    • Anemia associated with chemotherapy (cancer patients receiving myelosuppressive chemotherapy).
    • HIV-associated anemia (due to zidovudine therapy).
  • Mechanism:
    • Binds to erythropoietin receptors in the bone marrow, stimulating the differentiation of erythroid precursors into mature RBCs.

 

4) Oprelvekin (Recombinant IL-11) → B) Thrombocytopenia associated with cancer chemotherapy

 

  • Oprelvekin is recombinant interleukin-11 (IL-11).
  • It increases platelet production in patients receiving chemotherapy.
  • Indications:
    • Thrombocytopenia associated with chemotherapy (prevents the need for platelet transfusions).
    • Post-bone marrow transplant recovery.
  • Mechanism:
    • Stimulates megakaryocyte proliferation and maturation, increasing platelet counts.
    • Unlike thrombopoietin receptor agonists (e.g., eltrombopag), oprelvekin directly stimulates platelet precursors without targeting the thrombopoietin receptor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hematopoietic Growth Factors:

choices.text: A - transducer for sensing fetal heart rate; B – transducer for sensing uterine contractions
A - transducer for sensing uterine contractions; B - transducer for sensing fetal heart rate
A - transducer for sensing uterine contractions; B – transducer for sensing maternal heart rate
A - transducer for sensing maternal heart rate; B - transducer for sensing fetal heart rate

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida in active labor is undergoing continuous fetal monitoring. Identify probe A and B in this image
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A - transducer for sensing uterine contractions; B - transducer for sensing fetal heart rate

 

  • Cardiotocography (CTG) is a non-invasive intrapartum fetal surveillance test that measures:

    • Fetal Heart Rate (FHR) (via Doppler ultrasound transducer)
    • Uterine contractions (via tocodynamometer)

     

Function of Each Probe:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A = FHR, B = Uterine contractions: Incorrect. A measures uterine contractions, not FHR.

 

Option C. A = Uterine contractions, B = Maternal HR: Incorrect. B detects fetal heart rate, not maternal heart rate.

 

Option D. A = Maternal HR, B = FHR: Incorrect. Maternal heart rate is not measured via CTG; separate ECG or pulse oximetry is needed.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with hypertension and ischemic heart disease is prescribed both metoprolol and diltiazem. Three days later, he presents with confusion, dizziness, and syncope. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and ECG shows third-degree AV block. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glucagon

 

  • Instead of simply asking about the contraindication of beta-blockers with non-dihydropyridine CCBs, this question pushes the examinee to choose the appropriate treatment. 
  • Glucagon is the antidote for beta-blocker toxicity because it increases intracellular cAMP independent of beta-adrenergic receptors, restoring heart rate and contractility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium bicarbonate: Used for tricyclic antidepressant toxicity, not beta-blocker/CCB toxicity.

 

Option B. Isoproterenol: A beta-agonist, but not the first-line treatment due to limited efficacy in severe bradycardia.

 

Option C. Calcium gluconate: Useful in calcium channel blocker toxicity, but does not counteract beta-blocker effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with beta-blocker toxicity (often worsened by calcium channel blockers), glucagon is the treatment of choice as it increases cAMP and improves cardiac contractility independent of beta-receptor activation.

questions.text:
Based on the histopathological image provided, match the following with their likely diagnosis? 

 

Column A:

 

 

Column B:

 

  1. Fuch's endothelial dystrophy
  2. Macular corneal dystrophy
  3. Granular corneal dystrophy type I
  4. Lattice corneal dystrophy
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

 

Granular corneal dystrophy type I (1-C):

 

  • Histology: Shows hyaline deposits, appearing as "crumb-like" or "snowflake" opacities in the corneal stroma.
  • Clinical Presentation: Discrete white granular opacities that do not initially affect vision but progress over time.

 

Lattice corneal dystrophy (2-D):

 

  • Histology: Characterized by amyloid deposits forming lattice-like branching stromal opacities, confirmed by Congo red staining and birefringence under polarized light.
  • Clinical Presentation: Recurrent corneal erosions leading to blurred vision from early adulthood.

 

Macular corneal dystrophy (3-B):

 

  • Histology: Displays diffuse stromal mucopolysaccharide deposits, leading to severe stromal haze and vision loss.
  • Clinical Presentation: Most severe of the corneal stromal dystrophies, presenting with early progressive vision loss.

 

Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy (4-A):

 

  • Histology: Characterized by guttae formation and Descemet's membrane thickening, leading to endothelial decompensation and corneal edema.
  • Clinical Presentation: Morning blurry vision due to overnight corneal swelling, which worsens with disease progression.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Alcain Blue Stain has been used to stain glycosaminoglycans in the corneal stroma - macular corneal dystrophy
  • Cornea Guttata (wart like excrescences of Descemet membrane can be seen) – Fuch’s endothelial dystrophy
  • Hyaline protein is stained bright red with Masson trichrome stain with clear intervening spaces between the deposits - Granular Dystrophy Type I
  • Amyloid deposits seen with Congo red stain - Lattice dystrophy

questions.text:
Which of the following parasites do not produce operculated eggs?

 

  1. Dipylidium caninum
  2. Hymenolepis nana
  3. Diphyllobothrium latum
  4. Fasciola hepatica
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 2

 

  • Operculated eggs are eggs that have a lid-like structure (operculum) at one end, which allows larvae to hatch and escape. These eggs are typically seen in trematodes (flukes) and some cestodes.

 

1. Dipylidium caninum (Tapeworm of dogs) → Non-operculated eggs

  • The eggs are contained within egg packets, which are released from gravid proglottids.
  • Transmission occurs when fleas (intermediate hosts) containing cysticercoid larvae are ingested by dogs, cats, or humans.

  • Diagnosis: Presence of egg packets in stool.

     

2. Hymenolepis nana (Dwarf Tapeworm) → Non-operculated eggs

  • The eggs are thin-shelled, oval, and contain a six-hooked oncosphere with polar filaments.
  • Transmission occurs via ingestion of contaminated food or water.
  • Diagnosis: Detection of non-operculated eggs in stool.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Diphyllobothrium latum: Diphyllobothrium latum (Fish Tapeworm) produces operculated eggs, so this option is correct.

 

4. Fasciola hepatica: Fasciola hepatica (Liver Fluke) produces operculated eggs, making this option correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Operculated eggs are characteristic of trematodes (flukes) and certain cestodes like Diphyllobothrium latum.
  • Cestodes like Dipylidium caninum and Hymenolepis nana produce non-operculated eggs.

questions.text: What does phase III represent in the below image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alveolar plateau

 

  • This image is a typical capnography waveform, which is used to monitor the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in respiratory gases. 
  • The waveform is divided into several phases, each representing a different part of the respiratory cycle.
  • Phase III: Alveolar Plateau: The alveolar plateau represents the exhalation of alveolar gas, where CO2 levels plateau as the majority of the air comes from the alveoli, which are rich in CO2. This phase is used to measure the end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2), which is the concentration of CO2 at the end of expiration. This value is an important parameter in anesthesia and critical care.

 

Explanation of the Phases:

 

  • Phase I: Respiratory Baseline
    • This phase corresponds to the beginning of exhalation, where the air coming out of the patient is from the dead space (areas of the lungs that do not participate in gas exchange, such as the trachea and bronchi), and should contain no CO2. The CO2 level during this phase should be 0 mmHg.
  • Phase II: Expiratory Upstroke
    • This phase represents the mixing of dead space air with alveolar air. The rapid rise in CO2 levels occurs as the exhaled air transitions from dead space air to alveolar air.
  • Phase 0: Inspiratory Downstroke
    • This phase occurs during the beginning of inspiration, where fresh gas enters the airways, and the CO2 concentration rapidly falls back to zero.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Capnography is an essential monitoring tool that provides continuous information about a patient's ventilatory status.

questions.text:
A researcher conducts a study on the prevalence of a newly emerging respiratory virus among individuals with different blood groups (A, B, AB, O) over various durations of illness. The following table presents the distribution of cases:

 

 

Based on this data, what is the degree of freedom (df) for this contingency table?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6

 

  • The degree of freedom (df) for a contingency table is determined using the formula:

 

df = (Number of Rows−1) × (Number of Columns−1) 

 

In the given dataset:

 

  • Number of rows (duration of illness categories) = 3
  • Number of columns (blood groups) = 4

 

Applying the formula:

 

df = (3−1) × (4−1) = 2×3 = 6 

 

Thus, the correct answer is 6.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To correctly calculate degrees of freedom (df) for a contingency table, use the formula:

 

 df = (Rows−1) × (Columns−1)

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with frequent falls, nausea, and difficulty with coordination. MRI shows a cystic and solid lesion in the cerebellum, and biopsy reveals biphasic regions with Rosenthal fibers. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pilocytic astrocytoma

 

  • Pilocytic astrocytomas are the most common benign brain tumors in children, frequently found in the cerebellum.
  • MRI shows a cystic lesion with an enhancing mural nodule.
  • Histopathology reveals biphasic regions with Rosenthal fibers, which are eosinophilic, corkscrew-like glial processes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medulloblastoma: Incorrect. Medulloblastomas are solid tumors with Homer-Wright rosettes, not cystic lesions with Rosenthal fibers.

 

Option B. Ependymoma: Incorrect. Ependymomas arise near ventricles and often exhibit perivascular pseudorosettes.

 

Option D. Meningioma: Incorrect. Meningiomas are slow-growing tumors attached to the dura and are rare in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pilocytic astrocytomas are benign pediatric brain tumors often found in the cerebellum and characterized by cystic lesions with Rosenthal fibers.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of recurrent episodes lasting 10-15 minutes, characterized by intense fear, chest pain, palpitations, and a feeling of imminent death. Between episodes, she is constantly worried about having another attack and has started avoiding crowded places. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Panic disorder with agoraphobia

 

  • The patient experiences recurrent, unexpected panic attacks lasting 10-15 minutes, characterized by intense fear, chest pain, palpitations, and a sense of impending doom. 
  • Additionally, she has developed persistent worry about future attacks and has started avoiding crowded places, which is characteristic of panic disorder with agoraphobia.

 

Key Features of Panic Disorder with Agoraphobia:

 

  • Recurrent, unexpected panic attacks (intense episodes of fear and autonomic symptoms)
  • Persistent concern about having another attack
  • Avoidance behavior (e.g., avoiding crowded places) due to fear of being in situations where escape may be difficult

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Social anxiety disorder: Involves intense fear of social scrutiny or embarrassment in social/performance situations. This patient’s fear is related to panic attacks, not social judgment.

 

Option B. Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD): GAD is characterized by excessive worry about multiple aspects of life (e.g., work, health) for ≥6 months, not sudden panic attacks.

 

Option D. Specific phobia: Specific phobia involves excessive fear of a particular object or situation (e.g., heights, elevators) rather than panic attacks and fear of future episodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with anticipatory anxiety. 
  • Patients may start ‘avoiding’ situations that they link with the panic attack. 
  • Agoraphobia is defined as the fear of places from which escape might be difficult, this includes fear of open spaces, crowded places, enclosed places, traveling alone, and public transport. 
  • Treatment includes a combination of pharmacotherapy [benzodiazepines for short term and SSRIs for long term] and psychotherapy [CBT, relaxation techniques].

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis and chronic kidney disease is posted for kidney transplant procedure under general anaesthesia. What would be the neuromuscular blocking agent of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cis-Atracurium

 

  • Cis-atracurium, the R-isomer of atracurium, also undergoes Hofmann elimination, which is a temperature and pH-dependent process independent of organ function. 
  • Cis-atracurium is preferred over atracurium because it releases less histamine and is less likely to cause hemodynamic instability or allergic reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atracurium: Atracurium is metabolized through Hofmann elimination and ester hydrolysis, which is independent of renal and hepatic function. However, atracurium can release histamine, which can cause hypotension and other allergic reactions.

 

Option B. Pancuronium: Pancuronium is a long-acting NMBA that is primarily eliminated by the kidneys. In a patient with CKD, its use could lead to prolonged neuromuscular blockade due to decreased clearance.

 

Option D. Rocuronium: Rocuronium is primarily eliminated by the liver, with a small portion excreted by the kidneys. In patients with liver dysfunction, the clearance of rocuronium might be affected, potentially leading to prolonged effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cis-atracurium is the neuromuscular blocking agent of choice in patients with liver and kidney dysfunction because its elimination via Hofmann degradation does not depend on renal or hepatic function, and it has a lower risk of histamine release compared to atracurium.

questions.text: A child presents with deformity in the lower limbs. Radiograph is shown below. Patient also has hypopigmented patches on the skin. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibrous dysplasia

 

  • This is a bone disorder where normal bone is replaced with fibrous tissue.
  • It can affect single bones (monostotic) or multiple bones (polyostotic).
  • Characteristic radiographic findings include: 
    • "Ground-glass" appearance of the bone.
    • Bone deformities, such as bowing of the long bones.
  • When fibrous dysplasia is associated with skin pigmentation (café-au-lait spots) and endocrine abnormalities, it is called McCune-Albright syndrome.
  • The café-au-lait spots associated with McCune-Albright syndrome, a form of polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, are often described as having "coast of Maine" borders, meaning irregular borders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paget's disease: Paget's disease is a disorder of bone remodelling, most common in older adults. While it causes bone deformities, it is not typically associated with hypopigmented skin patches in the way that fibrous dysplasia is.

 

Option C. Non-ossifying fibroma: Non-ossifying fibroma is a benign bone tumour, usually found incidentally on radiographs. It typically does not cause significant bone deformity or skin changes.

 

Option D. Osteogenesis imperfecta: Osteogenesis imperfecta is a genetic disorder characterized by brittle bones. It is associated with blue sclerae (blue tinge to the whites of the eyes), and other symptoms, but not the same kind of skin pigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fibrous dysplasia is the combination of bone deformity and hypopigmented skin patches, particularly in a child, is a strong indicator of fibrous dysplasia, especially when considering McCune-Albright syndrome.

questions.text: A 56-year-old hospitalized patient with a history of multiple urinary tract infections (UTIs) is now presenting with a multi-drug resistant bacterial infection. Laboratory reports confirm the presence of plasmid-mediated antibiotic resistance genes. Which of the following mechanisms is most commonly responsible for the transfer of drug resistance among bacterial populations?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Conjugation and Enzyme Inactivation

 

  1. Conjugation
    • It is the most common method of horizontal gene transfer (HGT) in bacteria.
    • It occurs via direct cell-to-cell contact through a pilus and involves the transfer of plasmids containing antibiotic resistance genes (R-plasmids).
    • This is highly efficient in Gram-negative bacteria, including Escherichia coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  2. Enzyme Inactivation
    • Some bacteria produce enzymes that degrade or modify antibiotics, making them ineffective.
    • Examples include:
      • β-lactamases (inactivate β-lactam antibiotics like penicillins and cephalosporins).
      • Aminoglycoside-modifying enzymes (AMEs) (inactivate aminoglycosides by acetylation, phosphorylation, or adenylation).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transduction and Transformation: Less common mechanisms of drug resistance transfer:

 

  • Transduction: Bacteriophages transfer genetic material but are not the primary mechanism for drug resistance.
  • Transformation: Some bacteria take up naked DNA from the environment, but this is not the most common resistance mechanism.

 

Option B. Mutation and Enzyme Inactivation:

 

  • Mutation in bacterial DNA can confer resistance (e.g., rifampin resistance via RNA polymerase mutations), but mutation alone is not the dominant mechanism.
  • Enzyme inactivation contributes, but it is most effective when combined with horizontal gene transfer.

 

Option D. Transformation and Mutation:

 

  • Transformation is a rare event and does not play a major role in bacterial resistance.
  • Mutation occurs in individual bacteria but does not efficiently spread resistance within bacterial populations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Conjugation is the most common mechanism of bacterial drug resistance transmission via plasmid-mediated gene transfer.
  • Enzyme inactivation (e.g., β-lactamases, aminoglycoside-modifying enzymes) is a key mechanism in bacterial resistance to antibiotics.
  • Other resistance mechanisms like transduction, transformation, and mutation play a role but are not the most common methods of resistance acquisition in bacterial populations.

choices.text: Increases with gestational age and plateaus at 34 weeks
By 12 weeks, plasma volume expands by approximately 30%

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents for a routine prenatal checkup. She reports feeling mild fatigue and occasional dizziness. Which of the following statements regarding blood volume changes in pregnancy is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) By 12 weeks, plasma volume expands by approximately 30%

 

  • Blood volume increases progressively during pregnancy, peaking at 40-45% above pre-pregnancy levels by 32-34 weeks of gestation.
  • This adaptation is essential for fetal oxygenation and uteroplacental perfusion, compensating for potential blood loss at delivery.
  • By 12 weeks, blood volume expansion is only ~15%, not 30%, making option C incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increases by 40-45% of nonpregnant volume: Correct – Blood volume increases significantly to support fetal growth.

 

Option B. Increases with gestational age and plateaus at 34 weeks: Correct – Blood volume increases with gestational age and reaches its peak by 32-34 weeks.

 

Option D. Increase is 40-80% with multifetal gestation: Correct – Multifetal pregnancies require greater blood volume expansion, sometimes reaching 80%.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
A 61-year-old man presents with:

 

  • Clinic BP: 165/98 mmHg
  • Ambulatory BP monitoring (daytime average): 158/94 mmHg (confirmed hypertension)

 

Investigations:

 

  • Serum urea: 7.1 mmol/L (elevated, normal: 2.5–7.0)
  • Serum creatinine: 131 µmol/L (elevated, normal: 60–110)
  • eGFR: 54 mL/min/1.73 m² (reduced, normal: >90) → Stage 3a Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)
  • Urinary albumin-creatinine ratio (ACR): 43 mg/mmol (elevated, normal: <3)

 

Which is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ramipril (ACE Inhibitor)

 

  • This patient has hypertension and chronic kidney disease (CKD) with proteinuria (ACR >30 mg/mmol). 
  • ACE inhibitors (e.g., ramipril) are the first-line treatment in CKD patients with hypertension and proteinuria.

 

Key Features of This Case Suggesting CKD with Hypertension:

 

  • Hypertension confirmed by ambulatory BP monitoring
  • Reduced eGFR (54 mL/min/1.73 m²) → Stage 3a CKD
  • Elevated urinary albumin-creatinine ratio (ACR 43 mg/mmol) → Significant proteinuria
  • CKD guidelines recommend ACE inhibitors or ARBs in patients with ACR >30 mg/mmol

 

Why ACE Inhibitors (Ramipril) in CKD?

 

  • Reduce intraglomerular pressure and slow CKD progression
  • Lower blood pressure
  • Reduce proteinuria (renal protective effect)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amlodipine (Calcium Channel Blocker - CCB):

 

  • Used as first-line for hypertension, but not for CKD with proteinuria.
  • ACE inhibitors are preferred in CKD because they reduce proteinuria and slow disease progression.
  • CCBs can be added later if BP remains uncontrolled.

 

Option B. Dapagliflozin (SGLT2 Inhibitor):

 

  • Beneficial for CKD with diabetes, but this patient does not have diabetes.
  • SGLT2 inhibitors are not first-line for hypertension management.

 

Option C. Lifestyle Modification:

 

  • Lifestyle changes (e.g., diet, exercise, salt restriction) are recommended but not sufficient alone for stage 3 CKD with proteinuria.
  • Pharmacological treatment is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypertension with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and proteinuria (ACR >30 mg/mmol) should be treated with an ACE inhibitor (e.g., ramipril) as first-line therapy. ACE inhibitors reduce blood pressure, lower proteinuria, and slow CKD progression.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with joint pain, morning stiffness lasting over an hour, and swelling in her wrists and small joints of the hands. Laboratory studies reveal a positive rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies. Which of the following genetic polymorphisms is most strongly associated with her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PTPN22

 

  • PTPN22 encodes a protein tyrosine phosphatase that plays a role in T-cell activation and is strongly associated with autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, type 1 diabetes, and inflammatory bowel disease. 
  • Its polymorphisms are among the most frequently implicated in autoimmunity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FOXP3: Mutations in FOXP3 are associated with IPEX syndrome, a rare systemic autoimmune condition.

 

Option C. AIRE: AIRE mutations cause autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (APS-1).

 

Option D. NOD2: Polymorphisms in NOD2 are associated with Crohn’s disease, not rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PTPN22 is a gene commonly implicated in autoimmune diseases, including rheumatoid arthritis, due to its role in T-cell regulation.

questions.text: During a surgical procedure, a surgeon uses the instrument shown in the image to harvest a graft. Which of the following is the correct identification of this instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Humby knife

 

  • The Humby knife is a specialized instrument used for harvesting split-thickness skin grafts. 
  • It allows for precise control over the depth and size of the skin graft, making it ideal for this purpose. 
  • The design includes a blade that can be adjusted to vary the thickness of the graft, which is crucial for ensuring graft viability and optimal healing of both the donor and recipient sites.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Dermatome: Incorrect. A dermatome is also used for harvesting skin grafts but is typically a more mechanized device, which can be electric or air-powered, and not the manual type shown in the image. 

 

Option B. Silver’s knife: Incorrect. Silver’s knife is used in podiatric surgery and other specific surgical procedures, not typically for harvesting skin grafts. 

 

Option C. Catlin amputating knife: Incorrect. The Catlin amputating knife is used for limb amputations and is characterized by a large, curved blade, which is not suitable for the delicate process of harvesting skin grafts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Humby knife is a surgical instrument specifically designed for manually harvesting split-thickness skin grafts, allowing for adjustable control over graft thickness and size.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is being evaluated for developmental delay and hepatosplenomegaly. His physical exam reveals coarse facial features and thickened cardiac valves. Enzyme analysis confirms a lysosomal storage disorder. Which of the following findings would most reliably differentiate Hurler syndrome from Hunter syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Presence of corneal clouding

 

  • Hurler syndrome (MPS I) has corneal clouding, while Hunter syndrome (MPS II) does not.
  • Both conditions share coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, and cardiac valve disease, but corneal clouding is the key distinguishing factor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of dysostosis multiplex: Incorrect. Both Hurler and Hunter syndromes have skeletal abnormalities.

 

Option B. Degree of hepatosplenomegaly: Incorrect. Hepatosplenomegaly occurs in both but is not a distinguishing feature.

 

Option D. Extent of neurological deterioration: Incorrect. Both can cause neurological decline, but it is more severe in Hurler syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The key distinguishing feature between Hurler (MPS I) and Hunter (MPS II) syndromes is that corneal clouding is present in Hurler syndrome but absent in Hunter syndrome.

 

Hunter vs. Hurler Syndrome:

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with enlarged, yellow-orange tonsils, hepatosplenomegaly, and peripheral neuropathy. Laboratory results show undetectable levels of HDL cholesterol. A mutation in which of the following genes is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ABCA1

 

  • Tangier disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the ABCA1 gene, which encodes a transporter involved in cholesterol efflux from cells to HDL.
  • Deficiency of ABCA1 prevents the formation of mature HDL, leading to undetectable HDL levels and cholesterol accumulation in tissues.
  • This leads to yellow-orange tonsils, neuropathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and corneal opacities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. APOB100 mutation - Familial Defective ApoB100: Incorrect. This affects LDL receptor binding, not HDL metabolism.

 

Option B. LDLR mutation - Familial Hypercholesterolemia: Incorrect. This leads to elevated LDL levels, not absent HDL.

 

Option D. LPL mutation - Familial Chylomicronemia Syndrome: Incorrect. This results in high triglycerides and eruptive xanthomas, not absent HDL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tangier Disease:

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is incidentally found to have a large, well-defined anterior mediastinal mass on routine imaging. A CECT chest is shown below. Which of the following clinical conditions is most likely associated with this radiologic finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myasthenia gravis
