  • CECT shows an anterior mediastinal mass, likely thymoma. 
  • Thymomas are tumors originating from the epithelial cells of the thymus and are often associated with paraneoplastic syndromes, particularly myasthenia gravis.
  • Approximately 15% of patients with myasthenia gravis have a thymoma, and about 30% of patients with a thymoma will develop myasthenia gravis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome: Incorrect. Associated with small cell lung cancer, not thymic tumors.

 

Option C. Sjögren syndrome: Incorrect. Primarily associated with lymphoproliferative disorders.

 

Option D. Goodpasture syndrome: Incorrect. Affects the lungs and kidneys, not the thymus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thymomas are often associated with myasthenia gravis, making it a key differential diagnosis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with aspiration pneumonia is started on an antibiotic that binds to the 50S ribosomal subunit and inhibits translocation. 48 hours later, his diarrhea worsens, and stool tests confirm Clostridium difficile infection (CDI). Which of the following antibiotics was most likely responsible for this complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clindamycin

 

  • This 72-year-old man with aspiration pneumonia was prescribed an antibiotic that binds to the 50S ribosomal subunit and inhibits translocation. 
  • Shortly after treatment, he develops severe diarrhea, and Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) is confirmed by stool testing.
    • Clindamycin is well known for its high risk of causing C. difficile infection.
    • It binds to the 50S ribosomal subunit, inhibiting bacterial translocation and disrupting protein synthesis.
    • Clindamycin has a strong association with disrupting normal gut flora, allowing overgrowth of C. difficile, leading to pseudomembranous colitis.
    • This can result in watery diarrhea, abdominal pain, fever, and life-threatening toxic megacolon in severe cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Azithromycin: False

 

  • Azithromycin is a macrolide that also binds to the 50S ribosomal subunit and inhibits translocation.
  • However, macrolides have a lower risk of C. difficile infection compared to clindamycin.
  • Macrolides are more commonly associated with QT prolongation and gastrointestinal upset, rather than severe antibiotic-associated diarrhea.

 

Option C. Doxycycline: False

 

  • Doxycycline is a tetracycline that binds to the 30S ribosomal subunit and prevents aminoacyl-tRNA attachment.
  • It is not strongly associated with C. difficile infections.
  • It is often used in patients at risk of CDI due to its lower impact on normal gut flora.

 

Option D. Linezolid: False

 

  • Linezolid binds to the 50S ribosomal subunit but inhibits bacterial initiation rather than translocation.
  • Although it can cause gastrointestinal side effects, its association with C. difficile infection is much lower than that of clindamycin.
  • Linezolid is more commonly associated with bone marrow suppression and serotonin syndrome when combined with SSRIs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clindamycin binds to the 50S ribosomal subunit and inhibits bacterial translocation, but it also disrupts the normal gut microbiome, leading to an increased risk of Clostridium difficile infection. 
  • When prescribing antibiotics, especially in elderly or hospitalized patients, the risk of C. difficile should be considered, and alternative antibiotics with a lower risk (e.g., doxycycline) should be preferred when possible.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe right upper quadrant abdominal pain. She has a history of recurrent biliary colic. On physical examination, she has mild tenderness in the right upper quadrant but no signs of peritonitis. An abdominal ultrasound reveals multiple gallstones, a bile duct diameter of 12 mm, and no evidence of wall thickening or pericholecystic fluid. Laboratory tests show the following:

 

  • Total Bilirubin: 2.8 mg/dL
  • Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP): 380 IU/L
  • AST/ALT: Mildly elevated

 

What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)

 

  • The patient presents with right upper quadrant pain, gallstones on ultrasound, an enlarged bile duct (12 mm), and elevated liver enzymes, particularly ALP and bilirubin. 
  • These findings are highly suggestive of choledocholithiasis (common bile duct stones).

 

Why MRCP?

 

  • MRCP is a non-invasive imaging technique that provides high-resolution visualization of the biliary tree.
  • It helps confirm the presence of common bile duct (CBD) stones before proceeding with an invasive therapeutic procedure.
  • MRCP is preferred as the initial diagnostic test before an interventional procedure like ERCP due to ERCP’s potential complications (pancreatitis, bleeding, perforation).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) 

 

  • ERCP is therapeutic rather than purely diagnostic. It is performed only after imaging confirms CBD stones.
  • Performing ERCP without prior MRCP risks unnecessary procedural complications.

 

Option C. Endoscopic Ultrasound (EUS) 

 

  • EUS is an alternative imaging technique for CBD stone detection but is less commonly used compared to MRCP in the initial evaluation.
  • EUS is more useful in patients with intermediate-risk of choledocholithiasis, while MRCP remains the first choice in high-risk patients.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy

 

  • Cholecystectomy is the definitive treatment for gallbladder stones but should not be performed before ruling out CBD stones.
  • Proceeding with surgery without addressing the suspected choledocholithiasis could lead to biliary obstruction and serious complications.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • In a patient with suspected choledocholithiasis, an MRCP should be the initial step to confirm the presence of common bile duct stones before proceeding with invasive therapeutic interventions like ERCP.

choices.text: Increases antibiotic entry into the cell

questions.text: A hospitalized patient with a chronic indwelling catheter develops a persistent infection despite appropriate antibiotic therapy. Further analysis reveals the presence of a bacterial biofilm on the catheter surface. Which of the following is not a property of biofilms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increases antibiotic entry into the cell

 

  • Biofilms are structured microbial communities enclosed in a self-produced extracellular matrix that helps bacteria adhere to surfaces and resist host defenses. 
  • They are commonly seen in infections associated with catheters, prosthetic devices, and chronic wounds.
  • Biofilms restrict antibiotic penetration, leading to antimicrobial resistance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Helps in adhesion: Bacteria within biofilms adhere to surfaces like catheters and implants, making infections persistent.

 

Option C. Decreases metabolism: Bacteria in biofilms enter a dormant state, reducing metabolic activity and making them less susceptible to antibiotics.

 

Option D. Acts as a mechanical barrier: The extracellular matrix impedes antibiotic penetration, making infections difficult to eradicate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Biofilms are organized bacterial communities embedded in a protective extracellular matrix.
  • They reduce antibiotic effectiveness by restricting penetration, decreasing metabolism, and enhancing resistance mechanisms.
  • Biofilms are commonly seen in indwelling medical devices (catheters, implants), dental plaques, and chronic infections.
  • Treatment requires biofilm-disrupting agents, higher antibiotic doses, and sometimes removal of infected devices.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding febrile seizures are true?

 

  1. Febrile seizures typically occur between 6 months and 5 years of age.
  2. Rectal diazepam or intranasal midazolam are the drugs of choice for acute seizure control.
  3. Ethosuximide is the preferred drug for treating febrile seizures.
  4. Phenobarbitone is the drug of choice for neonatal seizures, not febrile seizures.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4

 

Statement 1. Febrile seizures typically occur between 6 months and 5 years of age: Febrile seizures occur in children aged 6 months to 5 years and are triggered by fever without underlying CNS infections.

 

Statement 2. Rectal diazepam or intranasal midazolam are the drugs of choice for acute seizure control: Rectal diazepam or intranasal midazolam are the first-line drugs for acute seizure management.

 

Statement 4. Phenobarbitone is the drug of choice for neonatal seizures, not febrile seizures: Phenobarbitone is not used for febrile seizures but is the drug of choice for neonatal seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A wrestler presents to OPD with complaints of recurrent shoulder dislocations. He gives history of 30 dislocations and dislocations while sleeping. His MRI shows Bankart tear and CT scan shows 40% bone loss from posterolateral aspect of head of humerus. What is the appropriate management here?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Latarjet procedure

 

Option B)

 

  • This patient has a classic case of recurrent anterior shoulder instability with significant bone loss. 
  • The history of 30 dislocations, including while sleeping, indicates severe instability.
  • Bankart tear is an avulsion of the anterior-inferior labrum from the glenoid, which is the most common lesion in traumatic anterior shoulder dislocations. 
  • Arthroscopic repair (Bankart repair) is a standard treatment but it is often insufficient when there is significant bone loss.
  • The CT scan shows 40% bone loss from the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head. This is a large Hill-Sachs lesion, which is a compression fracture of the humeral head caused by it impacting the anterior rim of the glenoid during dislocation. 
  • In addition, the repeated dislocations likely cause significant glenoid bone loss, further destabilizing the joint.
  • With a bone loss of 25% or more, a simple soft tissue procedure like an arthroscopic Bankart repair is very likely to fail. Therefore, the Latarjet procedure is the gold standard for this scenario.
  • Latarjet procedure is an open procedure that involves transferring the coracoid process (with its attached tendons) to the anterior glenoid.   
  • It addresses both soft tissue and bony defects. 
  • It provides a "triple effect": bone block, tendon sling, and capsular repair. 
  • This procedure effectively reduces the risk of re-dislocation in patients with significant bone loss from the glenoid and humeral head, making it the most suitable option for this wrestler.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arthroscopic Bankart Repair: Arthroscopic Bankart repair is the procedure that repairs the torn labrum. It is effective for isolated Bankart tears with minimal bone loss. With 40% bone loss, a Bankart repair alone will not provide sufficient stability. The large Hill-Sachs lesion will continue to engage the glenoid rim, leading to further dislocations.

 

Option C. McLaughlin Procedure: McLaughlin procedure is primarily used for posterior shoulder dislocations with impacted fractures of the humeral head. The patient has anterior instability and a Hill-Sachs lesion, not a posterior dislocation or fracture.

 

Option D. Remplissage Procedure: Remplissage Procedure is an arthroscopic procedure that involves filling the Hill-Sachs defect with the infraspinatus tendon. It's often used in conjunction with a Bankart repair. While it addresses the Hill-Sachs lesion, it doesn't address the glenoid bone loss, and with 40% humeral head bone loss, a remplissage alone will not be enough to prevent redislocation. Also, the remplissage procedure is often performed arthroscopically, and the Latarjet procedure is an open procedure. With that amount of bone loss, an open procedure is often preferred.   

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Latarjet procedure is the most appropriate management. 
  • The patient's recurrent dislocations, dislocations while sleeping, and significant bone loss necessitate a procedure that provides both soft tissue and bony stabilization.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with:

 

  • Painless, enlarged neck lump
  • Severe itching for the past 2 months
  • Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV), managed with an INSTI-based regimen

 

Examination findings:

 

  • Palpable, rubbery, nontender lymph node in her right neck
  • Small, firm, and nontender lymph nodes in her axilla bilaterally

 

Investigations:

 

  • Haemoglobin: 109 g/L (Normal: 115–165)
  • MCV: 87 fL (Normal: 80–96)
  • Eosinophils: 0.72 × 10⁹/L (Normal: 0.0–0.6)
  • Lymph node biopsy: 

 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hodgkin’s lymphoma

 

  • The patient's symptoms and biopsy findings strongly suggest Hodgkin's lymphoma. Here's why:
    • Painless, enlarged lymph node: Hodgkin lymphoma often presents with painless, rubbery, non-tender lymph nodes, commonly in the neck or axilla, as in this patient.
    • Severe itching (pruritus): Pruritus is a common symptom in Hodgkin's lymphoma, and it may occur in up to 25% of patients.
    • Reed-Sternberg cells on lymph node biopsy: The presence of Reed-Sternberg cells is the hallmark of Hodgkin lymphoma. These are large, abnormal cells that are characteristic of the disease and are not seen in non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
    • Eosinophilia: Elevated eosinophils, as seen here, are commonly associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma due to the production of IL-5, a cytokine that promotes eosinophil production.
    • Normocytic anaemia: Commonly seen in Hodgkin's lymphoma due to chronic disease, though it is nonspecific.
  • Additionally, Hodgkin lymphoma has a strong association with HIV, with patients having a higher risk of developing this cancer due to immunosuppression.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML): AML typically presents with bone marrow failure, leading to symptoms like fever, fatigue, and bleeding, not primarily with painless lymphadenopathy. AML is also not characterized by Reed-Sternberg cells.

 

Option B. Chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML): CML generally presents with splenomegaly, leukocytosis, and fatigue, and is characterized by elevated white blood cells. It does not present with Reed-Sternberg cells or lymphadenopathy as the primary feature.

 

Option D. Multiple myeloma: Multiple myeloma typically presents with bone pain, hypercalcaemia, renal failure, and elevated proteins (e.g., monoclonal gammopathy), not painless lymphadenopathy. It also does not feature Reed-Sternberg cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hodgkin lymphoma is a lymphatic cancer characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells on biopsy.
  • Common symptoms include painless lymphadenopathy, pruritus, night sweats, fever, and weight loss.
  • Eosinophilia is frequently observed, and Hodgkin lymphoma is more common in HIV-infected individuals.
  • The treatment for Hodgkin's lymphoma involves chemotherapy, often combined with radiotherapy.

questions.text: A randomized controlled trial was conducted to compare the efficacy of two drugs in treating a medical condition. The study results showed a statistically significant difference between the two drugs, with a p-value of <0.005. However, in reality, both drugs have the same efficacy and there is no actual difference. This scenario is an example of which of the following statistical errors?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type I error 

 

  • A Type I error (α error) occurs when a study incorrectly rejects the null hypothesis (H₀) when it is actually true. 
  • In this case, the null hypothesis states that there is no difference between the two drugs, but the study results incorrectly suggest that a difference exists. 
  • The probability of making a Type I error is denoted by α, which is typically set at 0.05 or lower (in this case, <0.005). 
  • This means the study found a false-positive result, concluding that the drugs are different when they are actually the same.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Type II error (beta error): This occurs when the null hypothesis is false, but we fail to reject it (false-negative result). This would mean not detecting a real difference when one actually exists, which is not the case in this scenario.

 

Option C. 1 – α (alpha): This represents the specificity or confidence level, which measures the probability of correctly failing to reject a true null hypothesis (i.e., avoiding Type I error).

 

Option D. 1 – β: This represents statistical power, which is the probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis (i.e., detecting a true effect when one exists).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A Type I error (α error) occurs when a study incorrectly rejects the null hypothesis (false-positive result). 
  • This happens when a statistically significant difference is found between groups, despite no actual difference in reality. 
  • The p-value (α level) represents the probability of committing this error, and lower p-values reduce the risk of false-positive findings.

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines is primarily responsible for the upregulation of E-selectin on endothelial cells during acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tumor necrosis factor (TNF)

 

  • E-selectin (CD62E) is expressed on endothelial cells activated by pro-inflammatory cytokines such as TNF and IL-1. 
  • These cytokines induce the synthesis of adhesion molecules, including E-selectin, which facilitates leukocyte rolling and adhesion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interferon-gamma (IFN-γ): IFN-γ is involved in macrophage activation and does not directly induce E-selectin expression.

 

Option B. Interleukin-4 (IL-4): IL-4 is associated with Th2 responses and does not upregulate E-selectin.

 

Option D. Transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-β): TGF-β is primarily anti-inflammatory and does not play a role in the induction of E-selectin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • E-selectin is upregulated on endothelial cells in response to pro-inflammatory cytokines like TNF and IL-1 during acute inflammation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pianist presents to the clinic with difficulty in fine motor movements of the hand, particularly when playing rapid sequences on the piano. What is the primary function of the muscle marked in the image at the metacarpophalangeal joint (MCP)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flexion 

 

  • The muscles marked in the image are the lumbricals, which play a key role in hand movements.
  • Function:
    • Flexion at the MCP joints
    • Extension at the interphalangeal (IP) joints
  • The lumbricals originate from the tendons of flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) and insert into the extensor expansion (extensor hood) of digits 2–5.
  • This unique dual function allows them to assist in making a precise grip while performing fine motor activities such as writing, playing the piano, or buttoning a shirt.

 

Innervation:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extension: The lumbricals extend the IP joints, but at the MCP joint, they cause flexion.

 

Option C. Adduction: Palmar interossei (not lumbricals) are responsible for adduction of fingers toward the midline.

 

Option D. Abduction: Dorsal interossei abduct the fingers, a function not performed by the lumbricals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lumbricals flex the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints while extending the interphalangeal (IP) joints, making them crucial for fine motor movements like writing and playing musical instruments.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman experiences sudden unconsciousness, with her husband describing:

 

  1. Stiffening of her body
  2. Jerking movements of her arms and legs for 2 minutes
  3. Postictal drowsiness upon regaining consciousness

 

What’s the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tonic-clonic seizure

 

  • This patient’s episode is highly characteristic of a generalized tonic-clonic seizure (previously called a "grand mal" seizure). 
  • The classic progression includes:
    1. Tonic phase (stiffening of the body) → Lasts a few seconds
    2. Clonic phase (rhythmic jerking movements of limbs) → Lasts 1–2 minutes
    3. Postictal phase (confusion, drowsiness, or fatigue) → Can last minutes to hours

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Absence seizure: Presents with brief episodes (5–10 sec) of staring or unresponsiveness without postictal drowsiness or tonic-clonic movements. More common in children.

 

Option B. Atonic seizure: Causes sudden loss of muscle tone, leading to a drop attack, not stiffening and jerking movements.

 

Option C. Focal aware seizure: Occurs with preserved consciousness and can involve isolated motor or sensory symptoms, but does not cause complete loss of consciousness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tonic-clonic seizures are characterized by a tonic phase (stiffening), followed by a clonic phase (jerking), and a postictal period (drowsiness/confusion). Diagnosis is clinical, and EEG/MRI may be needed for further evaluation. First-line treatment includes sodium valproate, levetiracetam, or lamotrigine.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with a history of irregular menstrual cycles presents with an early pregnancy. Based on her last menstrual period (LMP), she is estimated to be 8 weeks pregnant. A transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) is performed, and the crown-rump length (CRL) measurement corresponds to 7 weeks and 4 days. What gestational age should be assigned to this pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 8 weeks 0 days

 

  • The first-trimester ultrasound (also called the dating scan) is the most accurate method for gestational dating.
  • The CRL (Crown-Rump Length) is the best parameter for gestational age determination in the first trimester.
  • When to adjust gestational age:
    • If LMP and CRL differ by >7 days, the ultrasound CRL is used.
    • If the difference is ≤7 days, the gestational age based on LMP is retained.
  • In this case, the LMP suggests 8 weeks, while CRL suggests 7 weeks 4 days (difference = 3 days).
    • Since the difference is less than 7 days, LMP-based dating is retained (8 weeks 0 days).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 7 weeks 4 days: Incorrect. CRL-based dating is used only if the difference is >7 days.

 

Option C. 6 weeks 4 days: Incorrect. The CRL does not correspond to 6 weeks 4 days, and this is not a valid adjustment.

 

Option D. Repeat scan in 1 week: Incorrect. A repeat scan is needed only if there is uncertainty about viability, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In early pregnancy, if the CRL and LMP-based gestational age differ by ≤7 days, the LMP-based dating is retained. If the difference is >7 days, the CRL-based dating is used.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of numbness and loss of sensation over his right cheek and lower ear. He also reports a thickened cord-like structure palpable along the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle. On examination, the nerve is tender and thickened, and hypopigmented anesthetic skin patches are noted on the face. A skin smear confirms Mycobacterium leprae infection. Which of the following nerve roots contribute to the thickened nerve marked in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) C2, C3

 

  • The thickened nerve in the image is the great auricular nerve, which arises from the cervical plexus (C2, C3).
  • It emerges from the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) and ascends along the external jugular vein.
  • It provides cutaneous sensation to the skin over the parotid gland, angle of the mandible, and lower ear.
  • Clinical relevance:
    • Leprosy: Mycobacterium leprae preferentially affects peripheral nerves, including the great auricular nerve, leading to thickening and loss of sensation.
    • Frey's Syndrome: Aberrant regeneration between the auriculotemporal and great auricular nerves leads to gustatory sweating (sweating while eating).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C1: The C1 spinal nerve does not contribute to sensory nerves, as it is purely motor.

 

Option B. C2: The great auricular nerve has contributions from both C2 and C3, making this answer incomplete.

 

Option C. C1, C2: Incorrect because C1 does not contribute to cutaneous sensory nerves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The great auricular nerve (C2, C3) is commonly affected in leprosy, leading to nerve thickening and sensory loss over the parotid region and lower ear.

choices.text: Inhibition of fibrinogen synthesis in the fetal liver
Impaired γ-carboxylation of glutamate residues in clotting factors
Direct inhibition of factor Xa in the coagulation cascade
Increased degradation of vitamin K by the fetal liver

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 14 weeks gestation presents for routine evaluation. She has a history of mechanical heart valve replacement and is currently on warfarin therapy. She is advised to switch to low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) for the remainder of her pregnancy. What is the primary mechanism by which warfarin affects coagulation in the fetus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Impaired γ-carboxylation of glutamate residues in clotting factors

 

  • Warfarin inhibits vitamin K epoxide reductase, preventing the activation of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X, protein C, and protein S).
  • Without vitamin K, γ-carboxylation of glutamate residues in these factors is impaired, leading to dysfunctional coagulation and an increased risk of hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of fibrinogen synthesis in the fetal liver: Incorrect. Warfarin does not affect fibrinogen synthesis.

 

Option C. Direct inhibition of factor Xa in the coagulation cascade: Incorrect. This describes the mechanism of rivaroxaban and apixaban, not warfarin.

 

Option D. Increased degradation of vitamin K by the fetal liver: Incorrect. Warfarin inhibits recycling of vitamin K rather than increasing its degradation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Warfarin inhibits vitamin K epoxide reductase, preventing γ-carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X, leading to increased bleeding risk.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with severe, painful nodules and cysts on his face and upper back. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 13-cis Retinoic Acid

 

  • Isotretinoin (13-cis retinoic acid) is the first-line treatment for severe, recalcitrant nodulocystic acne.
  • It reduces sebaceous gland activity, normalizes keratinization, and has anti-inflammatory properties.
  • It is the most effective treatment for severe acne and provides long-term remission in many cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic Steroids:

 

  • Steroids are not the primary treatment for nodulocystic acne.
  • They may be used for severe inflammatory conditions but can cause acne flare-ups upon discontinuation.

 

Option C. Benzoyl Peroxide:

 

  • A topical antibacterial agent used for mild to moderate acne.
  • It reduces bacterial colonization and inflammation, but not sufficient for severe nodulocystic acne.

 

Option D. Estrogen:

 

  • Hormonal therapy (e.g., estrogen, anti-androgens) may help in hormonal acne in females.
  • However, it is not the primary treatment for nodulocystic acne in males.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Treatment of Severe Acne

Isotretinoin is the treatment of choice for severe nodulocystic acne due to its ability to reduce sebaceous gland activity and inflammation, leading to long-term remission.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the neurology clinic with loss of general sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Further evaluation reveals no impairment of taste sensation, and motor functions of the tongue are intact. Suspecting cranial nerve involvement, an MRI is performed. Upon review, you initially hypothesize damage to a nucleus of the Special Visceral Afferent (SVA) column but later realize that a particular nucleus you considered is actually not part of the SVA system. Which of the following cranial nerve nuclei was mistakenly believed to be part of the SVA column but is actually not?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trochlear nerve

 

  • The trochlear nerve (CN IV) nucleus belongs to the General Somatic Efferent (GSE) column, not the Special Visceral Afferent (SVA) column.
  • The trochlear nerve is purely motor, innervating the superior oblique muscle of the eye.
  • SVA fibers are associated with taste and olfaction, and their nuclei include:
    • Nucleus solitarius (for CN VII, IX, X), which processes taste sensation.

 

Cranial Nerve Columns:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial nerve: The facial nerve (CN VII) carries SVA fibers for taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

 

Option C. Vagus nerve: The vagus nerve (CN X) has SVA fibers for taste sensation in the epiglottis.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) has SVA fibers for taste from the posterior third of the tongue.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A mutation in hydroxymethylbilane synthase (HMB synthase) results in increased porphobilinogen levels. What is the major biochemical consequence of this enzymatic defect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Impaired uroporphyrinogen formation

 

  • Hydroxymethylbilane synthase catalyzes the polymerization of four porphobilinogen molecules into hydroxymethylbilane, which is a precursor for uroporphyrinogen.
  • Deficiency results in the accumulation of porphobilinogen and decreased production of downstream heme intermediates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased heme production: Incorrect. Heme production is decreased, not increased.

 

Option B. Increased ammonia production: Incorrect. Biochemical consequence of HMB synthase deficiency is the accumulation of porphobilinogen, not the production of ammonia.

 

Option C. Increased bilirubin synthesis: Incorrect. Bilirubin is a breakdown product of heme and is not affected in AIP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hydroxymethylbilane synthase deficiency leads to porphobilinogen accumulation and impaired uroporphyrinogen synthesis.

choices.text: Tight junctions are composed of connexins and allow ion passage between cells.
Adherens junctions provide anchoring support and are composed of cadherins.
Gap junctions form a strong mechanical attachment between adjacent cells.
Desmosomes form channels for communication between cells.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the cellular junctions shown in the image is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adherens junctions provide anchoring support and are composed of cadherins.

 

  • Adherens junctions are anchoring junctions made of cadherins, providing mechanical stability between cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tight junctions are composed of connexins and allow ion passage between cells: Tight junctions are made of claudin & occludin, not connexins.

 

Option C. Gap junctions form a strong mechanical attachment between adjacent cells: Gap junctions allow electrical communication, not strong mechanical attachment.

 

Option D. Desmosomes form channels for communication between cells: Desmosomes provide mechanical strength, not intercellular channels.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Adherens junctions anchor epithelial cells and are composed of cadherins.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding vaccine strains are true?

 

  1. The Nakayama strain is used in the Japanese encephalitis vaccine.
  2. The Jeryl Lynn strain is used for the mumps vaccine.
  3. The Oka strain is used for the measles vaccine.
  4. The Edmonston Zagreb strain is used for the measles vaccine.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4

 

Statement 1. The Nakayama strain is used in the Japanese encephalitis vaccine: The Nakayama strain is used for Japanese encephalitis.

 

Statement 2. The Jeryl Lynn strain is used for the mumps vaccine: The Jeryl Lynn strain is used for mumps.

 

Statement 4. The Edmonston Zagreb strain is used for the measles vaccine: The Edmonston Zagreb strain is for measles.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 3. The Oka strain is used for the measles vaccine: The Oka strain is for varicella, not measles.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about the phases of wound healing are correct?

 

  1. The inflammatory phase of wound healing begins immediately after injury and lasts for 2-3 days, involving vasoconstriction and thrombus formation to limit blood loss.
  2. During the proliferative phase, which lasts from the 3rd day to the 3rd week, fibroblast activity results in the production of collagen and proteoglycans, and is characterized by intense angiogenesis.
  3. The remodeling phase starts after the 3rd week, during which Type I collagen replaces Type III collagen, achieving a 4:1 ratio, and wound strength reaches a maximum by the 12th week post-injury.
  4. In the remodeling phase, the total tensile strength of the wound can surpass that of uninjured skin.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

Statement 1 (Correct): The inflammatory phase is accurately described, focusing on immediate responses like vasoconstriction and thrombus formation to prevent blood loss.

 

Statement 2 (Correct): The proliferative phase involves fibroblast activity, collagen production, and angiogenesis, crucial for rebuilding the damaged tissue.

 

Statement 3 (Correct): In the remodeling phase, Type I collagen replaces Type III collagen, and maximum wound strength is typically achieved around the 12th week, reaching approximately 80% of the strength of uninjured skin.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 4 (Incorrect): The wound strength, although significantly restored, typically does not surpass that of uninjured skin.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: VZV serological testing followed by vaccination if seronegative
VZV serological testing followed by varicella zoster Immunoglobulin if seronegative
VZV serological testing followed by varicella zoster immunoglobulin and vaccination if seronegative

questions.text: A 28-year multigravida presents at 6 weeks complaining of fever and a pruritic rash. You diagnose her with varicella zoster virus. Three of your other pregnant patients were in the office waiting room at the same time as this patient and you are concerned, they may have been exposed. Two of them report having a history of varicella during childhood and the 3rd reports no history of either vaccination or natural infection. What is the next best plan for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) VZV serological testing followed by varicella zoster Immunoglobulin if seronegative

 

  • Varicella infection in pregnancy is high-risk, particularly in the first and third trimesters, with risks including:
    • Congenital varicella syndrome (CVS) (if infected <20 weeks).
    • Severe maternal varicella pneumonia.
    • Neonatal varicella (if maternal infection occurs near delivery).

 

Management of Varicella Exposure in Pregnancy:

 

 

  • Vaccination is contraindicated in pregnancy, so Options A and D are incorrect.
  • VZIG is given to susceptible pregnant women within 10 days of exposure to reduce the risk and severity of infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vaccination now: Incorrect. Live attenuated varicella vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

 

Option B. VZV serological testing followed by vaccination if seronegative: Incorrect. Serological testing is correct, but vaccination is NOT given during pregnancy.

 

Option D. VZV serological testing followed by varicella zoster immunoglobulin and vaccination if seronegative Incorrect. VZIG is given, but vaccination is deferred until postpartum.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with chronic liver disease due to autoimmune hepatitis undergoes a liver biopsy. Histopathology reveals lymphocytes inside hepatocytes without evidence of phagocytosis or cell destruction. This finding is most consistent with which of the following processes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emperipolesis

 

  • Emperipolesis describes the movement of live immune cells inside another cell without being destroyed.
  • It is seen in autoimmune hepatitis, where lymphocytes migrate into hepatocytes but remain intact.
  • Unlike phagocytosis, emperipolesis does not involve degradation of the internalized cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Efferocytosis: Incorrect. Efferocytosis refers to engulfment of dying cells, not living cells.

 

Option C. Entosis: Incorrect. Entosis involves live-cell invasion followed by destruction, unlike emperipolesis.

 

Option D. Enclysis: Incorrect. Enclysis refers to the confinement of CD4+ T cells within hepatocytes, not general lymphocyte migration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Emperipolesis is the movement of live cells inside another cell without destruction and is seen in autoimmune hepatitis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of progressive hair thinning and hair loss over the past few years. He has a strong family history of male pattern baldness. The physician diagnoses him with androgenic alopecia and discusses treatment options. Which of the following is contraindicated in the treatment of androgenic alopecia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Testosterone

 

  • Androgenic alopecia (male pattern baldness) is caused by dihydrotestosterone (DHT), which binds to hair follicle receptors and causes miniaturization and progressive hair loss.
  • Testosterone supplementation increases DHT levels, worsening hair loss.
  • Therefore, testosterone and other androgens are contraindicated in androgenic alopecia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dutasteride:

 

  • It is used to treat androgenic alopecia by reducing DHT levels with its inhibition of both type I and type II enzymes. 
  • Therefore, dutasteride is beneficial and not contraindicated, aligning with the treatment options discussed for hair loss.

 

Option C. Finasteride:

 

  • A 5-alpha-reductase inhibitor that prevents the conversion of testosterone to DHT.
  • FDA-approved for treating male androgenic alopecia by reducing DHT levels.

 

Option D. Minoxidil:

 

  • A topical vasodilator that stimulates hair growth and delays follicle miniaturization.
  • First-line treatment for androgenic alopecia, available over the counter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Testosterone is contraindicated in androgenic alopecia as it increases DHT, worsening hair loss.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman who was treated with chemoradiation for Stage IIB squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix presents with severe menopausal symptoms including hot flashes, vaginal dryness, and mood disturbances. She has an intact uterus and is seeking treatment for her symptoms. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Conjugated estrogen with progesterone

 

  • Cervical cancer is not estrogen-dependent, so hormone therapy (HT) is not contraindicated in these patients.
  • Pelvic radiation therapy for cervical cancer induces ovarian failure, leading to early menopause with severe symptoms.
  • Estrogen therapy is strongly considered for premenopausal women undergoing radiation treatment for cervical cancer until they reach the average age of menopause (~51 years).
  • In women with an intact uterus, estrogen must be combined with progesterone to prevent endometrial hyperplasia and cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clonidine: Incorrect – Clonidine is a non-hormonal option for menopausal symptoms but is less effective than estrogen therapy.

 

Option B. Conjugated estrogen alone: Incorrect – Unopposed estrogen increases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and cancer in women with an intact uterus.

 

Option C. Vaginal estrogen cream: Incorrect – Vaginal estrogen helps with local symptoms (vaginal atrophy, dryness) but does not address systemic symptoms like hot flashes.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: All are taken at rest, except for total vaginal length, which is obtained during Valsalva
Point D is omitted in the absence of a cervix
GH is measured from the midline of the posterior hymenal ring to the mid-anal opening
Point Aa corresponds to the most distal portion of any part of the upper/proximal anterior vaginal wall

questions.text: A 60-year-old multiparous woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of vaginal bulging, urinary incontinence, and pelvic discomfort for the past year. On examination, a Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) system is used to assess the degree of prolapse. Which statement is true regarding measurements taken for the Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Point D is omitted in the absence of a cervix

 

  • The Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) system is a standardized system developed by the International Continence Society (ICS) for evaluating pelvic organ prolapse (POP).
  • Measurements are taken during Valsalva, except for Total Vaginal Length (TVL), which is measured at rest.
  • Point D (posterior fornix) is omitted if the patient has undergone a total hysterectomy, making option B correct.

 

 

POP-Q Measurement Key Points:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All are taken at rest, except for total vaginal length, which is obtained during Valsalva: Incorrect. All measurements (except TVL) are taken during Valsalva to assess maximum prolapse.

 

Option C. GH is measured from the midline of the posterior hymenal ring to the mid-anal opening: incorrect.GH is measured from the middle of the external urethral meatus to the posterior hymenal ring. The perineal body (PB) is measured from the posterior hymenal ring to the mid-anal opening.

 

Option D. Point Aa corresponds to the most distal portion of any part of the upper/proximal anterior vaginal wall: Incorrect. Point Aa is a fixed point (3 cm proximal to the external urethral meatus). Point Ba represents the most distal portion of the upper anterior vaginal wall in case of prolapse.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset severe chest pain radiating to his back. He has a history of hypertension, and an urgent CT aortogram reveals an aortic dissection extending to the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm at the level of T12. The consulting physician explains that the dissection could potentially affect all the structures passing through this opening. Which of the following does not pass through the aortic opening of the diaphragm?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vagal trunk

 

  • The aortic hiatus is located at the T12 vertebral level and allows the passage of:
    • Aorta (main artery supplying the body).
    • Thoracic duct (largest lymphatic vessel draining into venous circulation).
    • Azygous vein (drains venous blood from the posterior thoracic wall into the superior vena cava).
  • The vagal trunk (CN X) does not pass through the aortic opening but instead traverses the esophageal opening at T10 along with the esophagus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aorta: Correct structure – The aorta passes through the aortic hiatus at T12 to enter the abdominal cavity.

 

Option B. Azygous vein: Correct structure – The azygous vein enters the abdomen via the aortic opening and connects with the inferior vena cava.

 

Option C. Thoracic duct: Correct structure – The thoracic duct, which drains lymph from most of the body, passes through the aortic opening at T12.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diaphragmatic Openings & Structures Passing Through:

choices.text: CT urography with excretory phase imaging

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with persistent hematuria and sterile pyuria undergoes a CT scan revealing urothelial thickening, multiple ureteric strictures, and focal areas of mural enhancement. Which of the following is the best imaging modality for further evaluation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CT urography with excretory phase imaging

 

  • CT urography is the best imaging modality to evaluate collecting system involvement in renal TB.
  • The excretory phase enhances visualization of strictures, caliectasis, and ureteric involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI with gadolinium contrast: Incorrect. Not the preferred modality for collecting system pathology.

 

Option C. Retrograde pyelography: Incorrect. Can evaluate ureteric strictures but is invasive and not first-line.

 

Option D. Radionuclide renal scan: Incorrect. Used to assess renal function, not structural changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CT urography with excretory phase imaging is the best modality to evaluate collecting system strictures in renal tuberculosis.

questions.text: A patient with lepromatous leprosy exhibits a predominantly Th2 immune response. Which of the following cytokines is most likely elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IL-4

 

  • Lepromatous leprosy is associated with a dominant Th2 response, which leads to ineffective macrophage activation and widespread mycobacterial dissemination.
  • IL-4 is a key Th2 cytokine that promotes antibody production but does not effectively activate macrophages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IL-2: Incorrect. IL-2 is involved in T-cell proliferation but does not drive a Th2 response.

 

Option B. IL-12: Incorrect. IL-12 promotes Th1 differentiation, which is deficient in lepromatous leprosy.

 

Option C. IFN-gamma: Incorrect. IFN-gamma is a Th1 cytokine that promotes macrophage activation, which is suppressed in lepromatous leprosy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lepromatous leprosy is associated with a Th2 response, leading to high IL-4 levels and ineffective macrophage activation.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with a smooth swelling in her neck, which has been gradually increasing in size over the past year. She has a history of bipolar disorder, managed with lithium three times a day for the past 2 years. Image of the neck is shown below. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Iatrogenic goitre

 

  • The patient presents with a gradually enlarging, smooth neck swelling (goitre) and has been on long-term lithium therapy for bipolar disorder. 
  • This is highly suggestive of an iatrogenic goitre, specifically due to lithium-induced thyroid dysfunction.

 

Why Lithium Causes Goitre:

 

Lithium affects the thyroid by:

 

  • Inhibiting thyroid hormone release: Blocks thyroglobulin proteolysis, reducing T3 and T4 secretion.
  • Reducing iodine uptake: Disrupts the sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) function.
  • Interfering with thyroglobulin structure: Inhibits the iodotyrosine coupling process, reducing hormone synthesis.
  • Causing thyroid cell hyperplasia: Compensatory TSH stimulation leads to thyroid gland enlargement (goitre).

 

Up to 50% of patients on long-term lithium develop thyroid abnormalities, including:

 

  • Goitre (most common)
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Thyroiditis (rare)

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Graves disease:

 

  • Causes diffuse goitre, but is typically associated with hyperthyroid symptoms (weight loss, tremor, heat intolerance, exophthalmos).
  • Lithium usually causes hypothyroidism, not hyperthyroidism.

 

Option B. Hashimoto thyroiditis:

 

  • Causes a firm, rubbery goitre, often with positive anti-TPO antibodies, but lithium-induced goitre is typically smooth and painless without antibody involvement.

 

Option D. Nontoxic multinodular goitre:

 

  • Typically presents with a nodular goitre, not a smooth, diffuse enlargement.
  • More common in iodine-deficient regions, not primarily associated with lithium use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Iatrogenic goitre is the most common thyroid disorder caused by long-term lithium use.
  • Pathophysiology: Lithium inhibits thyroid hormone release, leading to TSH stimulation and thyroid enlargement.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Smooth, diffuse goitre
    • Symptoms of hypothyroidism (if severe): Fatigue, cold intolerance, constipation
  • Management:
    • Thyroid function tests (TFTs): To check for hypothyroidism (e.g., elevated TSH, low T4)
    • Ultrasound thyroid: To assess goitre characteristics
    • Lithium dose adjustment or thyroid hormone replacement (e.g., levothyroxine) if hypothyroidism develops

questions.text:
A 21-year-old woman presents with chest pain that worsens on inspiration. She recently recovered from an upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) two weeks ago. On examination, a friction rub is heard in both systole and diastole. Her ECG was shown in image below:

 

 

Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute pericarditis

 

  • Acute pericarditis is inflammation of the pericardium, often following a viral infection, and presents with:
    • Pleuritic chest pain (worsens with inspiration, improves when sitting up and leaning forward).
    • A pericardial friction rub (highly specific).
    • ECG: Widespread concave ("saddle-shaped") ST elevation and PR depression.
  • Acute pericarditis leads to abnormal repolarization due to pericardial inflammation, causing diffuse ST elevation across multiple leads, unlike STEMI, which affects specific regions.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Constrictive pericarditis: Causes chronic symptoms such as right heart failure (peripheral edema, ascites, raised JVP) rather than acute pleuritic pain.

 

Option C. Pulmonary embolism (PE): Can cause pleuritic chest pain but typically presents with sinus tachycardia, right heart strain pattern (S1Q3T3), or non-specific ECG changes, not widespread ST elevation.

 

Option D. ST-elevated myocardial infarction (STEMI): STEMI shows localized ST elevation in specific leads with reciprocal ST depression, while pericarditis causes diffuse, concave ST elevation and PR depression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute pericarditis should be suspected in young patients with recent viral infections, pleuritic chest pain, a pericardial rub, and widespread concave ST elevation on ECG.

questions.text: Match the following types of spina bifida with their respective characteristics:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-B, 2-C, 3-A, 4-D

 

  • Spina bifida occulta (1-B): Bony defect in vertebrae, no protrusion of meninges or cord.
  • Meningocele (2-C): Herniation of meninges through the bony defect, spinal cord remains intact.
  • Myelomeningocele (3-A): Herniation of both meninges and spinal cord, leading to severe neurological deficits.
  • Rachischisis (4-D): Severe form with an open neural tube exposed to the external environment.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Mr. Ramesh, a 62-year-old man from Mumbai, presents with progressive shortness of breath and fatigue over the past few weeks. He has a history of hypertension managed with amlodipine.

 

On physical examination:

 

  • Bilateral pitting edema up to the knees
  • Bibasal crepitations on chest auscultation
  • S3 heart sound

 

Chest x-ray shown below: 

 

 

Which is the most suitable diagnostic investigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Echocardiogram

 

  • The clinical signs of dyspnea, fatigue, pitting edema, bibasal crepitations, and an S3 heart sound suggest heart failure (most likely due to systolic dysfunction).
  • An S3 heart sound occurs due to blood oscillating within the ventricular walls during early diastole, often seen in systolic heart failure.
  • The most suitable investigation for heart failure is an echocardiogram, as it allows assessment of ejection fraction (EF), valvular function, and ventricular size.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic ultrasound (US): Used to assess abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA), not relevant in this case.

 

Option B. Serum brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels: Elevated BNP suggests heart failure, but it does not confirm the underlying cause or assess heart function.

 

Option C. Coronary angiography: Useful for evaluating coronary artery disease (CAD), which may contribute to heart failure, but it is not the first-line test for diagnosing heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An echocardiogram is the gold standard for diagnosing heart failure by assessing ejection fraction, ventricular function, and valvular pathology.

questions.text: A 26-year-old nulliparous woman presents with subfertility for 3 years and recurrent vaginal discharge. She has a history of an ectopic pregnancy in the past. A transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) is performed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrosalpinx

 

  • Hydrosalpinx refers to a fluid-filled, distended fallopian tube due to distal tubal obstruction, commonly caused by pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), previous ectopic pregnancy, or tubal surgery.
  • The TVS findings of a retort-shaped hypoechoic fluid-filled structure in the adnexa are highly suggestive of hydrosalpinx.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Subfertility/infertility (due to impaired tubal function).
    • Recurrent vaginal discharge.
    • History of ectopic pregnancy/PID.
    • Ultrasound finding: Retort-shaped, thin-walled fluid-filled tube.

 

Ultrasound Features of Hydrosalpinx:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ovarian malignancy: Incorrect – Ovarian malignancy presents with a solid-cystic mass, irregular borders, and ascites, not a thin-walled retort-shaped collection.

 

Option B. Endometriotic ovarian cyst - "Chocolate cyst": Incorrect – Endometriomas appear as ground-glass echogenicity cysts, not as hydrosalpinx.

 

Option D. Broad ligament fibroid: Incorrect – Fibroids are solid masses, whereas hydrosalpinx is fluid-filled.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following disorders with their primary characteristics:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-3, B-1, C-4, D-2

 

A) Somatic symptom disorder (SSD) → 3. One or more somatic symptoms causing distress or disruption of daily life

 

  • SSD is characterized by excessive thoughts, feelings, or behaviors related to distressing physical symptoms, which significantly impact daily functioning.

 

B) Illness anxiety disorder (IAD) → 1. Preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious illness

 

  • Patients with IAD have an excessive fear of having or developing a serious illness, despite minimal or no somatic symptoms. They frequently seek medical reassurance.

 

C) Conversion disorder (Functional Neurological Symptom Disorder) → 4. Neurological symptoms inconsistent with recognized neurological or medical conditions

 

  • Conversion disorder presents with neurological symptoms (e.g., weakness, paralysis, blindness, seizures) that are incompatible with known medical conditions and often arise in response to psychological stress.

 

D) Factitious disorder → 2. Intentional production or feigning of physical or psychological signs or symptoms

 

  • Factitious disorder involves the deliberate fabrication or exaggeration of symptoms for the primary purpose of assuming the sick role, without external incentives (e.g., financial gain).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Somatic symptom disorder involves excessive distress over physical symptoms, while illness anxiety disorder is marked by excessive fear of illness without significant symptoms. 
  • Conversion disorder presents with neurological deficits that lack medical explanation, and factitious disorder involves intentional symptom fabrication for psychological reasons.

choices.text: Elevated orotic acid levels in urine

questions.text: A neonate with lethargy and respiratory alkalosis is suspected to have a urea cycle disorder. Which of the following findings would most strongly suggest ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency over other urea cycle disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Elevated orotic acid levels in urine

 

  • OTC deficiency results in carbamoyl phosphate accumulation, which spills over into the pyrimidine synthesis pathway, increasing orotic acid levels in urine.
  • Other urea cycle defects do not produce orotic aciduria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased arginine in plasma: Incorrect. Arginine is usually depleted in UCDs.

 

Option C. Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN): Incorrect. UCDs reduce BUN because nitrogen is not efficiently excreted.

 

Option D. Excessive glycine accumulation: Incorrect. Glycine accumulation is not a feature of OTC deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Elevated orotic acid in urine is a hallmark of OTC deficiency, distinguishing it from other urea cycle disorders.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with schizophrenia has been on antipsychotic therapy for the past 6 months. During a routine follow-up, his physician notes that he has gained 12 kg (26 lbs) and his blood pressure is elevated (145/92 mmHg). His fasting glucose is 115 mg/dL and triglycerides are 230 mg/dL. Which of the following antipsychotic medications has the highest potential to cause this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clozapine

 

  • Metabolic syndrome is a well-known side effect of atypical (second-generation) antipsychotics (SGAs) and includes:
    • Weight gain
    • Dyslipidemia (high triglycerides, low HDL)
    • Hyperglycemia/diabetes mellitus
    • Hypertension
  • Among SGAs, clozapine and olanzapine have the highest risk of causing metabolic syndrome due to their strong antagonism of histamine (H1) and serotonin (5-HT2C) receptors, leading to:
    • Increased appetite
    • Reduced energy expenditure
    • Insulin resistance
  • Risperidone and quetiapine have moderate risk, while aripiprazole has the lowest risk of metabolic side effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Risperidone: Moderate risk of metabolic syndrome

 

  • Less weight gain than clozapine but still significant

  • Can cause hyperprolactinemia (leading to gynecomastia and amenorrhea)

     

Option C. Quetiapine: Moderate risk of metabolic syndrome

 

  • Causes weight gain and dyslipidemia but less than clozapine
  • Sedation is a major side effect due to strong antihistamine effects

 

Option D. Aripiprazole: Lowest risk of metabolic syndrome

 

  • Partial dopamine agonist (D2) with minimal metabolic effects
  • Preferred in patients at risk of diabetes or obesity

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clozapine and olanzapine have the highest risk of metabolic syndrome among atypical antipsychotics, while aripiprazole has the lowest risk. 
  • Patients on high-risk SGAs should have regular monitoring of weight, blood glucose, and lipid levels.

choices.text: Inhibition of RNA polymerase II transcription
Failure to splice pre-mRNA into mature mRNA

questions.text: A scientist genetically modifies a cell line to knock out the Dicer gene. What is the most likely consequence of this modification?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased translation of target mRNAs

 

  • Dicer is necessary for the processing of miRNAs and siRNAs, which function to silence gene expression.
  • Without Dicer, miRNA-mediated gene silencing is impaired, leading to increased translation of target mRNAs and upregulation of gene expression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased DNA replication efficiency: Incorrect. Dicer is involved in RNA processing, not DNA replication.

 

Option C. Inhibition of RNA polymerase II transcription: Incorrect. RNA polymerase II remains active even in the absence of Dicer.

 

Option D. Failure to splice pre-mRNA into mature mRNA: Incorrect. Splicing is performed by the spliceosome, not by Dicer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dicer inhibition prevents the formation of miRNAs, leading to increased translation of target mRNAs due to loss of post-transcriptional gene silencing.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are correct, and the reason correctly explains the assertion.
Both assertion and reason are correct, but the reason does not explain the assertion.
Assertion is correct, but the reason is incorrect.
Both assertion and reason are incorrect.

questions.text:
Assertion: Gap junctions facilitate electrical coupling between cardiac muscle cells.

 

Reason: Gap junctions are made up of connexons, allowing ion exchange.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both assertion and reason are correct, and the reason correctly explains the assertion.

 

  • Gap junctions facilitate electrical conduction in cardiac muscle.
  • Connexons, composed of connexins, allow the passage of ions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Gap junctions are crucial in cardiac muscle for electrical conduction through connexons, enabling synchronized contractions.

choices.text: Increasing vegetable intake in primary school meals from 50g to 100g.
Reducing oil and fat consumption to prevent excess calorie intake.
Increasing food grains by 50 grams per child per day.
Doubling the pulses intake while keeping other components constant.

questions.text: Which of the following adjustments to the Mid-Day Meal Scheme would be most beneficial in reducing micronutrient deficiencies among primary school children?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increasing vegetable intake in primary school meals from 50g to 100g.

 

  • Vegetables are rich in essential vitamins and minerals (iron, folic acid, vitamin A, vitamin C). 
  • Increasing their portion from 50g to 100g would help combat micronutrient deficiencies such as anemia and vitamin A deficiency, which are common among school children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reducing oil and fat consumption to prevent excess calorie intake: Reducing oil and fat would decrease calorie intake, which is not beneficial since many children already face undernutrition.

 

Option C. Increasing food grains by 50 grams per child per day: Increasing food grains would only boost carbohydrate intake without significantly improving micronutrient density.

 

Option D. Doubling the pulses intake while keeping other components constant: While pulses are a good source of protein, micronutrient deficiencies require vitamins and minerals, which are better obtained from vegetables.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To reduce micronutrient deficiencies, increasing vegetable intake is more effective than increasing calories or proteins alone.

     

Summary:

 

 

The Mid-Day Meal Scheme is designed to address malnutrition and school attendance but requires home supplementation to fully meet dietary needs. Enhancing vegetable intake, balancing protein sources, and ensuring additional micronutrient-rich foods can further improve its effectiveness.

choices.text: Folliculogenesis is entirely under the control of FSH.
Estrogen is secreted by theca cells of pre-antral & antral follicles.
The Graafian follicle is selected based on the number of FSH receptors on its surface.
The tertiary follicle contains a secondary oocyte along with granulosa & theca cells.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents to the fertility clinic with concerns about irregular menstrual cycles and difficulty conceiving. Laboratory tests reveal elevated FSH levels and ultrasound shows multiple antral follicles, but none developing into a dominant follicle (Graafian follicle). Which of the following statements about folliculogenesis is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The Graafian follicle is selected based on the number of FSH receptors on its surface.

 

  • Folliculogenesis is the maturation process of ovarian follicles, which begins as a hormone-independent process up to the secondary follicle stage.
  • After this stage, FSH and LH play a critical role in follicular growth.
  • The Graafian follicle is selected based on the highest number of FSH receptors, allowing it to respond more effectively to circulating FSH and outcompete other follicles.

 

Two- Cell, Two-Gonadotropin Theory:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folliculogenesis is entirely under the control of FSH: Initial folliculogenesis is hormone-independent up to the secondary follicle stage. FSH & LH become crucial only after the antral follicle stage.

 

Option B. Estrogen is secreted by theca cells of pre-antral & antral follicles: Theca cells do not secrete estrogen; they produce androgens, which are converted into estrogen in granulosa cells via aromatase.

 

Option D. The tertiary follicle contains a secondary oocyte along with granulosa & theca cells: All follicles contain a primary oocyte until just before ovulation. The secondary oocyte forms only after the Graafian follicle matures and undergoes the first meiotic division.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

The Graafian follicle is selected based on the number of FSH receptors on its surface, ensuring it responds optimally to FSH stimulation and progresses to ovulation.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man presents with:

 

  • Severe pain and swelling in his right big toe (1st metatarsophalangeal joint) for 1 day.
  • Difficulty walking due to pain.
  • Temperature: 38.3°C (low-grade fever).
  • Image of the toe is shown below:

 

 

Which is the most appropriate investigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Synovial fluid analysis

 

This presentation is highly suggestive of acute gout (podagra), characterized by:

 

  • Acute onset of severe joint pain and swelling (often affecting the 1st metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint).
  • Erythema and tenderness (suggesting inflammation).
  • Low-grade fever (systemic inflammatory response).

 

Why is synovial fluid analysis the most appropriate test?

 

  • Confirms gout by identifying negatively birefringent, needle-shaped monosodium urate crystals.
  • Excludes septic arthritis, which can mimic acute gout but requires urgent antibiotics.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Anti-CCP antibodies: Used to diagnose rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which presents with chronic, symmetric polyarthritis rather than acute, monoarticular inflammation.

 

Option B. Dual-energy CT: Can detect urate crystal deposits in chronic gout, but synovial fluid analysis is the gold standard for acute gout.

 

Option C. Schirmer test: Used to diagnose Sjögren’s syndrome (measures tear production), which has no relevance to gout or acute arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute gout (podagra) presents with sudden severe pain, swelling, and erythema in the 1st MTP joint. 
  • Synovial fluid analysis is the gold standard test, confirming negatively birefringent, needle-shaped urate crystals and ruling out septic arthritis.

questions.text:
Which of the following bacterial structures contribute to antigenic activity on the bacterial surface?

 

  1. Capsular polysaccharide 
  2. Pilli 
  3. Flagella 
  4. Nuclear membrane 
  5. Cell wall
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 5

 

Antigenic activity in bacteria occurs due to structures that elicit an immune response and can be recognized by the host immune system. These structures include:

 

1. Capsular polysaccharide: The bacterial capsule is made of polysaccharides that help evade phagocytosis and act as an antigen (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae).

 

2. Pili (Fimbriae): These are proteinaceous appendages that aid in attachment to host cells and immune evasion (e.g., Neisseria gonorrhoeae).

 

3. Flagella: These are whip-like structures made of flagellin, which is recognized by Toll-like receptor 5 (TLR5) and contributes to antigenic variation (e.g., Salmonella, Escherichia coli).

 

5. Cell wall: In gram-positive bacteria, it contains peptidoglycan and teichoic acids, while gram-negative bacteria have lipopolysaccharides (LPS) in the outer membrane, both of which serve as antigens.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Nuclear membrane: This is incorrect because bacteria are prokaryotic organisms and lack a nuclear membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bacterial antigenic structures include the capsule, pili, flagella, and cell wall, which help in immune evasion, attachment, and pathogenicity. 
  • The capsular polysaccharide is a key virulence factor in many pathogens like Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae.
  • Pili and flagella contribute to motility, adherence, and antigenic variation, making them important vaccine targets.
  • Cell wall components (peptidoglycan, teichoic acid, LPS) trigger innate immune responses, making them important diagnostic markers.

choices.text: High case finding but Low TCNR

questions.text: A district surveillance report shows that among tuberculosis (TB) patients tested, 15% are found to be HIV positive. According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) guidelines, how should this district be categorized?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High TB-HIV

 

  • The National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) classifies districts based on TB notification rates, case detection efforts, and the prevalence of co-infections, such as HIV and drug-resistant TB (DR-TB).
  • A district is categorized as High TB-HIV when more than 10% of TB patients in the district are found to be HIV positive. Since this district has 15% of TB patients testing positive for HIV, it falls into the High TB-HIV category under the NTEP guidelines.
  • HIV-positive individuals have a significantly higher risk of developing active TB disease due to immune suppression, which makes co-infection surveillance crucial. 
  • The High TB-HIV classification allows for enhanced screening, prompt initiation of antiretroviral therapy (ART) and TB treatment, and preventive strategies to reduce transmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High TB: The High TB category applies to districts with a TB case notification rate exceeding 180 per lakh population. This question, however, focuses on TB-HIV co-infection, which follows a different classification criterion.

 

Option C. Very low case finding effort: A district is categorized as Very Low Case Finding Effort if the annual suspect TB examination rate is <400 per lakh population. However, this question does not provide any data regarding TB screening rates, so this option is not applicable.

 

Option D. High case finding but Low TCNR: A district falls under this category when the annual suspect TB examination rate is >1200 per lakh population, but the TB case notification rate is <80 per lakh population. The given case does not mention TB case notification rates or testing rates exceeding 1200 per lakh, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), a district is categorized as High TB-HIV if more than 10% of tuberculosis (TB) patients tested are HIV positive. 
  • This classification allows targeted HIV-TB co-infection management, including early detection, ART initiation, and improved TB control strategies.

 

Categorization of Districts under NTEP (for HIV-TB Co-infection)

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman with a history of recurrent respiratory infections presents with a productive cough with purulent sputum and occasional blood in her sputum for the past 2 years. She has bilateral finger clubbing and bilateral coarse crepitations on chest auscultation.

 

Investigation:

 

CXR:

 

 

Based on the image and the history, what’s the patient’s underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bronchiectasis

 

  • This patient’s symptoms of a productive cough with purulent sputum, occasional haemoptysis, and recurrent chest infections, along with bilateral finger clubbing and coarse crepitations, are characteristic of bronchiectasis.
  • The CXR findings of dilated, thickened bronchial walls and tramline markings suggest the presence of cylindrical bronchiectasis, which is the most common type. 
  • Bronchiectasis occurs due to chronic airway inflammation and infection, leading to permanent dilation of the airways. 
  • The tramline markings seen on the CXR represent the dilated bronchial walls.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: Asthma typically presents with wheezing, shortness of breath, and reversible airflow obstruction, and is not associated with the chronic productive cough, blood-streaked sputum, and clubbed fingers seen in this case.

 

Option C. Extrinsic allergic alveolitis: Extrinsic allergic alveolitis (also known as hypersensitivity pneumonitis) presents with acute or subacute symptoms like cough, dyspnoea, and fever following exposure to an inhaled antigen. It typically does not cause productive sputum or finger clubbing in the chronic form, which is more suggestive of bronchiectasis.

 

Option D. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis presents with progressive dyspnoea, dry cough, and fine crackles on auscultation. It is associated with honeycombing on CXR and CT, but the findings of productive cough, purulent sputum, and tramline markings are more indicative of bronchiectasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bronchiectasis is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by dilated, thickened airways and a productive cough, often with purulent sputum and occasional haemoptysis. CXR findings of tramline markings are characteristic of bronchiectasis, particularly the cylindrical type.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents to the labor room at midnight complaining of vaginal leaking for several hours. On examination, the uterus is at term, and the fetus is in transverse lie. Fetal heart sounds are absent, and on vaginal examination, the umbilical cord is prolapsed into the vagina. The cervix is 5 cm dilated, and the presenting part is high up. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency lower segment cesarean section (LSCS)

 

  • This case describes a transverse lie with cord prolapse in a dead fetus.
  • Despite fetal demise, cesarean section is still indicated to prevent obstructed labor and maternal complications.
  • Vaginal delivery is not possible in a transverse lie, and labor augmentation will not correct the lie or resolve cord prolapse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Augment labor with oxytocin: Incorrect – Oxytocin does not correct a transverse lie and may lead to obstructed labor.

 

Option C. External Cephalic Version - ECV: Incorrect – ECV is contraindicated during labor and is only performed before labor in a singleton pregnancy.

 

Option D. Internal Podalic Version: Incorrect – Internal podalic version is used for second twin delivery, not for singleton transverse lie.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic for a routine check-up. The pediatrician palpates the infant's skull and notices that most fontanelles are still open. The parents ask about the sequence of fontanelle closure and its clinical significance. Which of the following fontanelles is the first to close in a normal infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior 

 

  • The posterior fontanelle is the first to close, usually by 3 months of age.
  • It is located at the junction of the sagittal and lambdoid sutures and is smaller than the anterior fontanelle.
  • Clinical significance:
    • Early closure can indicate craniosynostosis.
    • Delayed closure can be seen in hydrocephalus, hypothyroidism, or Down The posterior fontanelle is the first fontanelle to close at 3 months of age.  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior fontanelle:

 

  • Largest fontanelle, located at the bregma (frontal & parietal bones).
  • Closes last (18-24 months), making this incorrect.

 

Option C. Occipital fontanelle: The posterior fontanelle is located in the occipital region, but the term "occipital fontanelle" is not commonly used in anatomical classification.

 

Option D. Mastoid fontanelle: Closes between 6-24 months, later than the posterior fontanelle.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A public health expert is assessing different strategies for healthy behaviour in a community setting. He wants to adopt an approach that ensures long-term behavior modification rather than immediate compliance. Which of the following approaches is most suitable for achieving this goal?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Health education approach

 

  • The health education approach focuses on long-term behavioral changes by educating individuals about health risks and preventive strategies. 
  • While this approach may be slow to yield results, it is the most sustainable method for modifying behavior and ensuring community self-reliance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Regulatory approach: Involves government intervention and legislative enforcement (e.g., mask mandates during pandemics), ensuring immediate compliance but not necessarily long-term behavior change.

 

Option B. Service approach: Focuses on providing healthcare at the doorstep without necessarily educating individuals, making it effective but not a sustainable solution for behavior change.

 

Option D. Primary healthcare approach: Involves community participation and intersectoral coordination, but its primary goal is self-reliance in health, not long-term behavioral modification through education.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The health education approach is crucial for long-term behavior change, as it focuses on educating individuals rather than enforcing rules or providing temporary solutions.

questions.text: A disaster response team is deployed to a combat zone where a missile strike has injured multiple soldiers. Due to limited medical resources, the team decides to treat walking wounded soldiers first to ensure they can return to combat. This is an example of which type of triage system?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reverse Triage

 

  • Reverse triage prioritizes less wounded individuals over critically injured patients.
  • It is commonly used in military settings where soldiers need to be returned to combat quickly.
  • It is also applied in disasters where medical resources must be conserved for patients with a higher survival chance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Simple Triage: Simple triage is used in mass casualty incidents to sort patients based on severity but does not prioritize less severe cases first.

 

Option C. Rapid Triage: Rapid triage (S.T.A.R.T.) is a field-based emergency triage system but does not follow the reverse priority approach.

 

Option D. Selective Triage: Selective triage is not a recognized category of triage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Reverse triage prioritizes less injured individuals when rapid return to duty or resource conservation is needed, such as in military or disaster scenarios.

questions.text: A district health administrator is working to integrate different healthcare services, ensuring common seniority, equal pay, and no private practice for government-employed doctors. These recommendations were proposed by which of the following committees?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Jungalwalla Committee (1967)

 

  • The Jungalwalla Committee (1967), also known as the Committee on Integration of Health Services, focused on unifying the healthcare system in India. Its recommendations included:
    • Unified health service structure
    • Common seniority across cadres
    • Equal pay for equal work
    • Abolition of private practice for government doctors
    • Better service conditions and incentives for specialists

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kartar Singh Committee, 1973: Recommended multipurpose health workers by replacing ANMs and male health workers.
