Option C. Chadah Committee, 1963: Focused on malaria vigilance operations and basic health worker deployment.

 

Option D. Mukherji Committee, 1966: Suggested that basic health services should be provided at the block level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Jungalwalla Committee (1967) played a key role in integrating India’s healthcare services by establishing uniformity in pay, service conditions, and cadre recognition.

questions.text: A 19th-century European country introduced a public health strategy that aimed to provide state-funded universal healthcare services. This system became a model for several other countries that later adopted similar approaches to healthcare delivery. Which country pioneered this system that is regulated by professional groups?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Russia

 

  • Russia is credited with introducing the concept of socialized medicine, ensuring state-funded healthcare for all citizens. 
  • This model was later adapted by many other countries, influencing the development of universal healthcare systems worldwide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Germany: Incorrect. Germany is known for introducing compulsory sickness insurance, not socialized medicine.

 

Option B. France: Incorrect. France contributed Germ Theory and Pasteurization, not socialized medicine.

 

Option D. Croatia: Incorrect. Croatia is associated with quarantine practices, not state-funded healthcare models.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contributions:

questions.text: What is the best treatment for a peripheral tear of meniscus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Repair

 

  • Peripheral tears, especially those in the outer "red zone" of the meniscus (which has a good blood supply), have a higher chance of healing. 
  • Repair is often the preferred option for these types of tears, particularly in younger, active individuals.   
  • Repair aims to stitch the torn meniscus back together, preserving its important function as a shock absorber.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Exercise: Exercise is a crucial component of both conservative and post-surgical treatment. Specific exercises can help strengthen the muscles surrounding the knee, improve stability, and reduce pain. In some cases of minor tears, exercise alone, as part of a conservative treatment plan, might be sufficient.

 

Option C. Reconstruct: "Reconstruct" isn't the typical terminology used for meniscus tears. The common surgical options are "repair" or "meniscectomy" (removal). In cases of severe meniscal deficiency, a Meniscus transplant could be performed.   

 

Option D. Conservative: Conservative treatment includes rest, ice, compression, elevation (RICE), pain medication, and physical therapy. This is often the first line of treatment, especially for smaller tears or in older individuals. Conservative treatment can be very effective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "red zone" vs. "white zone": 

 

  • The outer third of the meniscus ("red zone") has a better blood supply, making repair more viable. 
  • The inner two-thirds ("white zone") has limited blood supply, so tears in this area are less likely to heal. 
  • If the tear is in the peripheral "red zone" then a repair is the best option. 
  • Conservative treatment is very often the first step in any treatment plan.

 

 

  • Patient factors: Age, activity level, and overall health play a significant role in treatment decisions.   
  • Tear characteristics: The size, location, and pattern of the tear influence treatment.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about Vaccine-Associated Paralytic Polio (VAPP) and Vaccine-Derived Poliovirus (VDPV) are true?

 

  1. VAPP occurs more commonly than cVDPV.
  2. cVDPV can cause outbreaks in low-immunization areas.
  3. The most common cause of cVDPV is poliovirus type 2.
  4. VAPP is a transmissible form of polio.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 3

 

Statement 2: "cVDPV can cause outbreaks in low-immunization areas." (True)

 

  • Circulating Vaccine-Derived Poliovirus (cVDPV) occurs when mutated poliovirus spreads within a population with low vaccine coverage.
  • Unlike VAPP, which is an isolated case, cVDPV behaves similarly to wild poliovirus, leading to outbreaks.
  • This is particularly seen in communities where OPV coverage is inadequate.

 

Statement 3: "The most common cause of cVDPV is poliovirus type 2." (True)

 

  • Poliovirus type 2 is the most common cause of cVDPV because it is the most likely to mutate and revert to a neurovirulent form.
  • In 2016, type 2 OPV was removed from routine immunization due to its high risk of causing cVDPV outbreaks.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 1: "VAPP occurs more commonly than cVDPV." (False)

 

  • VAPP is a rare event, occurring in approximately 1 in 2.7 million OPV doses.
  • cVDPV is even rarer, but it can cause outbreaks in populations with low vaccination coverage.
  • However, cVDPV has become more significant in recent years, particularly after the withdrawal of type 2 OPV from routine immunization.

 

Statement 4: "VAPP is a transmissible form of polio." (False)

 

  • VAPP is not transmissible; it remains confined to the individual recipient of OPV.
  • In contrast, cVDPV can spread in a community, leading to secondary cases and outbreaks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • VAPP is a rare, isolated case of poliomyelitis caused by OPV mutations and does not spread between individuals. 
  • In contrast, cVDPV arises when OPV-derived poliovirus mutates and circulates in a low-vaccine-coverage community, leading to outbreaks. Poliovirus type 2 is the most common cause of cVDPV.

choices.text: White matter gliosis from previous ischemic injury

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman with a history of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex and mild intellectual disability undergoes routine brain imaging. Which of the following best explains these MRI findings as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neuronal migration abnormalities (radial bands)

 

  • TSC is associated with defective neuronal migration, leading to radial bands on T2-weighted MRI.
  • These bands extend from the periventricular region to the cortex and contribute to developmental delay and epilepsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. White matter gliosis from previous ischemic injury: Incorrect. TSC is a genetic disorder, not a result of ischemia.

 

Option C. Periventricular leukomalacia due to prematurity: Incorrect. Seen in preterm infants, not in TSC.

 

Option D. Chronic inflammatory demyelination: Incorrect. This would be seen in MS or ADEM, not TSC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Radial bands in TSC result from neuronal migration defects and appear as hyperintense streaks on T2-weighted MRI.

choices.text: Wad, made of plastic or cardboard

questions.text: During an autopsy, a gunshot wound was found with evidence of multiple pellet impacts. The pellets were likely kept together until impact by a specific component in the cartridge. What is this component, and what is its usual material?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wad, made of plastic or cardboard

 

  • The wad in a shotgun cartridge is used to keep pellets together during firing and is typically made from plastic or cardboard. 
  • This component fits within the scenario described, where multiple pellet impacts suggest that the pellets were grouped together until they hit the target, a function performed by the wad.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primer, made of lead peroxide: The primer ignites the gunpowder and does not keep pellets together.

 

Option B. Cartridge case, made of alloy: The cartridge case holds all components but is not specifically responsible for keeping pellets together.

 

Option C. Bullet casing, made of metal: The bullet casing is part of the cartridge but does not keep pellets together.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Key components of a cartridge:

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida is in active labor. On vaginal examination, the fetal head is engaged, what is the fetal position in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left occipito posterior

 

  • Fetal position is determined by the relationship of the occiput (posterior fontanelle) to the maternal pelvis.
  • In this image:
    • The occiput (posterior fontanelle) is towards the right side of the maternal pelvis.
    • The occiput is posterior (closer to the sacrum).
    • This indicates a Right Occipito-Posterior (ROP) position.

 

Fetal Positions Based on Occiput Location:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LOA - Left Occipito-Anterior: Incorrect because the occiput is on the right side of the maternal pelvis.

 

Option B. LOP - Left Occipito-Posterior: Incorrect because the occiput is on the right, not the left.

 

Option C. ROA - Right Occipito-Anterior: Incorrect because in ROA, the occiput is anterior (near the pubis), not posterior.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with fever, headache, and cough for 1 week. A chest X-ray shows diffuse interstitial infiltrates, and he is started on an antibiotic targeting an organism lacking a cell wall. Which of the following antibiotics was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Azithromycin

 

  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae lacks a cell wall, making beta-lactams (e.g., ceftriaxone) ineffective.
  • Macrolides (e.g., azithromycin) are the treatment of choice for atypical pneumonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ceftriaxone: False, Beta-lactams target the cell wall, which Mycoplasma lacks.

 

Option B. Vancomycin: False, targets peptidoglycan, ineffective for Mycoplasma.

 

Option D. Meropenem: False, Carbapenems act on cell wall synthesis, ineffective for Mycoplasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae lacks a cell wall and is treated with macrolides (azithromycin) or tetracyclines (doxycycline).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with cirrhosis is given diazepam for alcohol withdrawal. He continues to experience prolonged sedation, and his physician suspects impaired drug metabolism. Which of the following metabolic reactions is most likely impaired in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydroxylation

 

  • Diazepam is metabolized by Phase I reactions, which include oxidation, reduction, and hydrolysis. 
  • These reactions occur primarily in the liver, and their efficiency decreases with aging and liver disease. 
  • Hydroxylation, a key Phase I reaction, is mediated by cytochrome P450 enzymes and is impaired in liver dysfunction, leading to prolonged drug effects.
  • In contrast, Phase II reactions (e.g., glucuronidation, acetylation, and sulfation) are often preserved in liver disease, making drugs that undergo Phase II metabolism (e.g., lorazepam, oxazepam, temazepam) safer in cirrhotic patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucuronidation: A Phase II microsomal reaction, typically preserved in liver disease. Drugs like morphine and bilirubin are metabolized this way.

 

Option C. Acetylation: A non-microsomal Phase II reaction important for metabolizing isoniazid and hydralazine, but not significantly affected by liver dysfunction.

 

Option D. Sulfation: Another non-microsomal Phase II reaction, important for drugs like acetaminophen, and less dependent on liver function than Phase I reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Phase I metabolism (oxidation, reduction, hydrolysis) is primarily mediated by cytochrome P450 enzymes and is impaired in liver disease, leading to prolonged drug effects. 
  • Phase II metabolism (glucuronidation, acetylation, sulfation) is generally preserved in hepatic dysfunction.

questions.text: A wildlife researcher develops biphasic fever after working in a rural area of Karnataka during the dry season. In the second phase of illness, he develops neurological symptoms, including meningoencephalitis. Which of the following is the primary amplifier host in this zoonotic disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Monkeys

 

  • The wildlife researcher in this case presents with a biphasic fever followed by neurological symptoms like meningoencephalitis, occurring during the dry season in Karnataka. 
  • These clinical features are highly suggestive of Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD), a zoonotic tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever caused by the Kyasanur Forest Disease Virus (KFDV), which belongs to the Flavivirus family.
  • Monkeys serve as the primary amplifier hosts in the KFDV transmission cycle.
  • When infected by tick bites, monkeys exhibit high viral loads, which allows further spread of the virus when ticks feed on them and subsequently transmit it to other susceptible hosts, including humans.
  • This is why KFD is also known as "Monkey Fever", as outbreaks are often linked to monkey die-offs, which serve as an early warning sign of human outbreaks.

 

Thus, monkeys are the correct answer as the primary amplifier host in the transmission cycle of Kyasanur Forest Disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Humans:

 

  • Humans are incidental dead-end hosts in the KFD transmission cycle, meaning they do not contribute to further spread of the virus.
  • Humans acquire the infection through tick bites (especially from Haemaphysalis spinigera), but they do not amplify the virus in a way that allows further transmission to ticks or other animals.
  • Unlike monkeys, humans do not develop high viremia, making them unlikely to be amplifier hosts.

 

Option B. Squirrels:

 

  • While squirrels are reservoir hosts for KFDV, they are not the primary amplifier hosts.
  • Reservoir hosts harbor the virus but do not necessarily increase its transmission the way an amplifier host does.
  • Squirrels, along with rats, maintain low levels of the virus in the environment but do not significantly contribute to human outbreaks.

 

Option D. Cattle:

 

  • Cattle are not involved in the transmission cycle of KFDV.
  • Unlike tick-borne diseases like Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF), in which livestock plays a role, KFD is primarily linked to monkeys, rodents, and ticks.
  • Cattle do not develop viremia or contribute to the transmission cycle of KFDV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) is a tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever endemic to Karnataka, India. 
  • Monkeys serve as the primary amplifier hosts, facilitating the spread of KFDV to tick populations. 
  • Humans are incidental dead-end hosts and do not contribute to further transmission. 
  • Squirrels and rodents act as reservoirs but not amplifiers, while cattle are not involved in KFD transmission.

questions.text: A 23-year-old college student is brought to the emergency department after ingesting a large dose of an unknown drug. The patient has tachycardia, mydriasis, hypertension, and agitation. Toxicology screening is positive for amphetamines. What is the best initial treatment to enhance drug elimination?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ammonium chloride

 

  • Amphetamines are weak bases, and their renal excretion increases in acidic urine. 
  • Ammonium chloride (NH₄Cl) acidifies urine, trapping ionized amphetamines and enhancing elimination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Activated charcoal: Useful for recent oral ingestion but does not enhance renal elimination.

 

Option B. Sodium bicarbonate: Alkalinizes urine, which would increase amphetamine reabsorption.

 

Option D. Hemodialysis: Amphetamines are not effectively removed by dialysis due to their large volume of distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amphetamine toxicity is managed by acidification of urine (e.g., with ammonium chloride) to enhance renal elimination.

 

Summary:

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of heavy smoking is diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung. Genetic analysis reveals no mutations in the DNA sequence of her tumor suppressor genes, yet their expression is significantly reduced. Which of the following epigenetic processes is most likely responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DNA methylation

 

  • DNA methylation is an epigenetic mechanism that involves the addition of methyl groups to cytosine residues in CpG islands, often leading to transcriptional silencing of genes, including tumor suppressor genes. 
  • Aberrant DNA methylation is frequently observed in cancers, contributing to the repression of genes without altering the DNA sequence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chromatin remodeling: While chromatin remodeling also plays a role in gene expression, it does not directly explain transcriptional silencing in the absence of DNA mutations.

 

Option C. Histone acetylation: Histone acetylation generally promotes gene expression rather than repressing it.

 

Option D. Gene duplication: Gene duplication refers to a structural alteration of the genome, not an epigenetic modification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Epigenetic mechanisms, such as DNA methylation, can silence tumor suppressor genes without altering the DNA sequence, contributing to cancer development.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements correctly describe the immediate management of suspected acute variceal bleeding? 

 

  1. Fluid resuscitation should be initiated to stabilize the patient, but hypervolemia must be avoided to prevent worsening portal hypertension.
  2. Intravenous octreotide should be started to reduce portal hypertension and help control bleeding.
  3. Prophylactic antibiotics should be given to reduce the risk of infections in cirrhotic patients with gastrointestinal bleeding.
  4. Emergency endoscopy is required to perform band ligation or sclerotherapy to achieve hemostasis.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Statement 1 (Correct): In acute variceal bleeding, fluid resuscitation should be done cautiously to maintain hemodynamic stability without inducing hypervolemia, which can worsen portal hypertension and bleeding.

 

Statement 2 (Correct): Octreotide, a somatostatin analog, reduces splanchnic blood flow and lowers portal pressure, helping control variceal bleeding. It is a first-line pharmacologic therapy in suspected variceal hemorrhage.

 

Statement 3 (Correct): Prophylactic antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone or norfloxacin) are essential in cirrhotic patients with gastrointestinal bleeding. They prevent spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) and other infections, which are common in these patients.

 

Statement 4 (Correct): Emergency endoscopy (within 12 hours) is performed to confirm the diagnosis and provide definitive treatment via endoscopic band ligation or sclerotherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Positive Stemmer's sign suggests the presence of lymphedema.
Negative Stemmer's sign indicates advanced peripheral arterial disease.
Positive Stemmer's sign is diagnostic of acute deep vein thrombosis.
Negative Stemmer's sign confirms the absence of connective tissue disease.

questions.text: What does Stemmer's sign indicate when evaluating a patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Positive Stemmer's sign suggests the presence of lymphedema.

 

  • Stemmer's sign is a clinical test used in the diagnosis of lymphedema. It involves attempting to pinch and lift the skin on the dorsum of the toes or fingers. 
  • A positive Stemmer's sign, where the skin cannot be easily pinched and lifted due to subcutaneous fibrosis, strongly suggests lymphedema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B, C, D: Incorrect. Negative Stemmer's sign does not specifically indicate advanced peripheral arterial disease, deep vein thrombosis or connective tissue disease, as the sign is specific to lymphatic system assessment.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Stemmers sign- a positive sign indicates the inability to pinch the skin due to subcutaneous thickening associated with lymphatic fluid accumulation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with irritable bowel syndrome with constipation (IBS-C) is prescribed a medication that activates chloride channels in the intestinal epithelium, leading to increased fluid secretion and softer stools. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lubiprostone

 

  • Lubiprostone is a chloride channel activator that increases intestinal fluid secretion, improving stool consistency and motility.
  • It is commonly used for IBS-C and chronic idiopathic constipation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prucalopride: False, a 5-HT₄ agonist that enhances motility but does not activate chloride channels.

 

Option C. Lactulose: False, an osmotic laxative that draws water into the colon but does not directly stimulate chloride channels.

 

Option D. Bisacodyl: False, a stimulant laxative that increases peristalsis but does not affect chloride secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lubiprostone activates chloride channels in the intestinal epithelium, increasing fluid secretion and motility, making it effective for IBS-C and chronic constipation.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding laryngeal nerve anatomy and function are correct? 

 

  1. The recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid muscle.
  2. The left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the aortic arch, making it more vulnerable to injury than the right.
  3. The internal laryngeal nerve provides motor innervation to the cricothyroid muscle.
  4. The recurrent laryngeal nerve provides sensory innervation to the larynx below the vocal cords.
  5. Damage to the recurrent laryngeal nerve can cause vocal cord paralysis.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4 and 5

 

Statement 1: The recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid muscle, which is supplied by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.

 

Statement 2: The left recurrent laryngeal nerve has a longer course as it loops around the aortic arch, making it more vulnerable to injury due to tumors, aneurysms, or surgery.

 

Statement 4: The recurrent laryngeal nerve provides sensory innervation below the vocal cords, while the internal laryngeal nerve supplies sensation above the vocal cords.

 

Statement 5: Damage to the recurrent laryngeal nerve can result in vocal cord paralysis, leading to hoarseness, breathy voice, or stridor in severe cases.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 3: Incorrect, The cricothyroid muscle is not innervated by the internal laryngeal nerve. Instead, it is supplied by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: The central part of the hard palate's bony structure is covered by a firmly attached mucosa.
The keratinized stratified squamous epithelium of the hard palate can be orthokeratinized or parakeratinized.
The mucosa that covers the hard palate has a distinct keratinized layer known as the stratum corneum.
The hard palate lacks a submucosal layer with blood vessels in the lateral parts.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents to the dental clinic complaining of persistent burning sensation and discomfort in her hard palate. She reports a history of chronic tobacco use and frequent consumption of hot beverages. Which of the following statements about the hard palate is not correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The hard palate lacks a submucosal layer with blood vessels in the lateral parts.

 

  • The hard palate is covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, which can be orthokeratinized or parakeratinized.
  • The central portion is tightly adhered to the underlying bone, making it firm and immobile.
  • The lateral regions of the hard palate do have a submucosal layer containing blood vessels and minor salivary glands (particularly in the posterior region).
  • This submucosal layer nourishes the mucosa and provides lubrication via mucous secretions, making option D incorrect.

 

Hard Palate Histology:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The central part of the hard palate's bony structure is covered by a firmly attached mucosa: Correct. The central hard palate mucosa is firmly attached to the bony structure, making it less flexible.

 

Option B. The keratinized stratified squamous epithelium of the hard palate can be orthokeratinized or parakeratinized: Correct. The hard palate can be orthokeratinized (no nuclei in keratin layer) or parakeratinized (retains condensed nuclei until exfoliation).

 

Option C. The mucosa that covers the hard palate has a distinct keratinized layer known as the stratum corneum: Correct. The mucosa has a distinct keratinized layer (stratum corneum), providing protection against mechanical stress from chewing and temperature variations.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of alcohol-related cirrhosis presents with hematemesis and melena. Endoscopy reveals actively bleeding esophageal varices. Which of the following drugs should be administered immediately to reduce portal pressure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Octreotide

 

  • Esophageal varices are caused by portal hypertension due to liver cirrhosis.
  • Acute variceal bleeding is a life-threatening emergency, requiring:
    • Hemodynamic stabilization (IV fluids, blood transfusion if needed).
    • Octreotide, which causes splanchnic vasoconstriction, reducing portal blood flow and lowering variceal pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propranolol: False, a non-selective beta-blocker used for variceal bleeding prophylaxis, not acute treatment.

 

Option C. Omeprazole: False, a PPI for GERD and ulcer prophylaxis, but does not reduce portal pressure.

 

Option D. Lactulose: False, used for hepatic encephalopathy, not variceal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Octreotide is used in acute variceal bleeding to decrease portal pressure via splanchnic vasoconstriction, reducing the risk of further hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency room after a motor vehicle accident. CT scan shows a grade III splenic laceration without evidence of hemodynamic instability. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-operative management with close monitoring

 

  • Non-operative management is appropriate for hemodynamically stable patients with splenic injuries, including grade III lacerations. 
  • This approach includes close monitoring of vital signs and hematocrit levels to ensure stability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate splenectomy: Incorrect as immediate splenectomy is reserved for hemodynamically unstable patients or those who fail non-operative management.

 

Option C. Angiography and possible embolization: Incorrect because angiography and embolization are considered if the patient becomes unstable or if there is evidence of ongoing bleeding.

 

Option D. Administration of prophylactic antibiotics: Incorrect as prophylactic antibiotics are not typically indicated in the management of isolated splenic injuries.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Non-operative management can be implemented for stable patients with splenic injuries, reserving more invasive measures for signs of instability or failure of conservative management.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1 woman with a history of Rh isoimmunization is undergoing fetal Doppler ultrasonography to assess for fetal anemia. Which fetal artery is being assessed to diagnose fetal anemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Middle cerebral artery

 

  • The Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) Doppler is the gold standard for diagnosing fetal anemia in cases of Rh isoimmunization, Parvovirus B19 infection, or other causes of fetal hemolysis.
  • In fetal anemia, there is decreased blood viscosity and compensatory increased cardiac output, leading to:
    • Increased blood flow to the fetal brain (brain-sparing effect).

Increased peak systolic velocity (PSV) in the MCA due to decreased hematocrit. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior cerebral artery: Incorrect – The anterior cerebral artery is not used in fetal anemia assessment.

 

Option C. Posterior cerebral artery: Incorrect – The posterior cerebral artery is also not used for this purpose.

 

Option D. Umbilical artery: Incorrect – Umbilical artery Doppler is used to assess placental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia, but not fetal anemia.

 

Key Doppler Findings in Fetal Anemia:

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Match the following types of nerve injuries with their corresponding descriptions:

 

Column A (Type of Nerve Injury):

  1. Neuropraxia
  2. Axonotmesis
  3. Neurotmesis
  4. Sunderland’s 3rd-degree injury
  5. Sunderland’s 4th-degree injury

 

Column B (Description):

  1. Axon, Endoneurium and Perineurium are damaged, but Epineurium is intact
  2. Temporary loss of nerve function without structural damage
  3. Axon and Endoneurium are damaged, but Perineurium and Epineurium remain intact
  4. Complete loss of nerve function with irreparable damage to all structures
  5. Axon is damaged, but connective tissues remain intact
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-B, 2-E, 3-D, 4-C, 5-A

 

  • Neuropraxia (1-B): Temporary nerve dysfunction without structural damage (e.g., compression injuries).
  • Axonotmesis (2-E): Axon is damaged but supporting connective tissues (Endoneurium, Perineurium) remain intact, allowing for recovery.
  • Neurotmesis (3-D): All nerve structures are damaged beyond repair.
  • Sunderland’s 3rd-degree injury (4-C): Axon and Endoneurium are damaged, but Perineurium and Epineurium are preserved, leading to partial regeneration potential.
  • Sunderland’s 4th-degree injury (5-A): Axon, Endoneurium and Perineurium are damaged, but Epineurium is intact, allowing only limited regeneration. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Neuropraxia: Temporary nerve dysfunction without structural damage (e.g., compression injuries).
  • Axonotmesis: Axon is damaged but supporting connective tissues (Endoneurium, Perineurium) remain intact, allowing for recovery.
  • Neurotmesis: All nerve structures are damaged beyond repair 
  • Sunderland’s 3rd-degree injury: Axon and Endoneurium are damaged, but Perineurium and Epineurium are preserved, leading to partial regeneration potential.
  • Sunderland’s 4th-degree injury: Axon, Endoneurium and Perineurium are damaged, but Epineurium is intact, allowing only limited regeneration.

questions.text: A pharmacologist is testing a new drug that acts as an enzyme inhibitor. The Lineweaver-Burk plot shows a shift in the x-intercept (−1/Km) toward the right without a change in the y-intercept (1/Vmax). What is the most likely mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Competitive inhibition

 

  • Competitive inhibitors bind to the active site, preventing substrate binding but not affecting enzyme function once bound.
  • Key Observations from the Graph:
    • x-intercept (−1/Km) shifts right (Km increases), meaning the enzyme requires more substrate to reach Vmax.
    • y-intercept (1/Vmax) remains unchanged, meaning Vmax is unchanged.
  • This behavior is characteristic of competitive inhibition, as increasing the substrate concentration can overcome inhibition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mixed inhibition: Incorrect. Mixed inhibition changes both Km and Vmax, rather than affecting only Km.

 

Option B. Non-competitive inhibition: Incorrect. Non-competitive inhibitors do not affect Km but decrease Vmax.

 

Option C. Uncompetitive inhibition: Incorrect. Uncompetitive inhibition decreases both Km and Vmax, causing a parallel shift.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Competitive inhibitors increase Km (shift x-intercept right) but do not affect Vmax, as they compete with the substrate for the active site.

 

Key Enzyme Inhibition Concepts

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with excessive thirst, polyuria, and fatigue. Blood glucose levels are normal. Further workup reveals hypernatremia, low urine osmolarity, and failure to concentrate urine after water deprivation. Which hormone dysfunction is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antidiuretic hormone (ADH)

 

  • Function: ADH (also called vasopressin) is secreted by the hypothalamus and released by the posterior pituitary gland. It increases water reabsorption in the collecting ducts of the kidneys by stimulating aquaporin channels, thereby concentrating urine.
  • Why Correct?
    • ADH deficiency results in diabetes insipidus (DI), characterized by polyuria (excessive urine output), excessive thirst (polydipsia), and dilute urine (low urine osmolarity).
    • Failure to concentrate urine after water deprivation is a classic feature of DI, confirming the lack of ADH activity.
    • Hypernatremia occurs due to excessive free water loss, as ADH is responsible for retaining water in the kidneys.
    • Central DI is caused by damage to the hypothalamus or pituitary (tumors, trauma, surgery), whereas nephrogenic DI is due to renal insensitivity to ADH (e.g., lithium toxicity).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aldosterone : Incorrect

 

  • Function: Aldosterone, secreted by the adrenal cortex, regulates sodium and water retention in the kidneys. It plays a major role in maintaining blood pressure and electrolyte balance.
  • Why Incorrect? Aldosterone dysfunction, such as in Addison’s disease (deficiency) or Conn’s syndrome (excess), affects sodium and potassium levels. It does not cause the polyuria and low urine osmolality seen in diabetes insipidus. Instead, aldosterone deficiency leads to hyponatremia and hyperkalemia, whereas excess aldosterone causes hypertension and hypokalemia, neither of which is seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Cortisol : Incorrect

 

  • Function: Cortisol, a glucocorticoid produced by the adrenal glands, is involved in metabolism, immune function, and stress response. It influences glucose metabolism and helps in sodium retention.
  • Why Incorrect? Cortisol excess (Cushing's syndrome) is associated with weight gain, hypertension, and hyperglycemia but does not cause significant polyuria or low urine osmolarity. Cortisol deficiency (Addison’s disease) leads to fatigue, hypotension, and electrolyte disturbances (hyponatremia, hyperkalemia), but not the pattern seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Insulin : Incorrect

 

  • Function: Insulin is a pancreatic hormone that regulates blood glucose by promoting glucose uptake into cells and inhibiting gluconeogenesis.
  • Why Incorrect? Diabetes mellitus (DM), caused by insulin deficiency (type 1) or resistance (type 2), does cause polyuria and polydipsia, but it is associated with hyperglycemia, not normal blood glucose. The patient’s normal blood glucose rules out diabetes mellitus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ADH plays a crucial role in water reabsorption.
  • Its deficiency leads to diabetes insipidus (DI), presenting with excessive thirst, polyuria, hypernatremia, and dilute urine.
  • Failure to concentrate urine after water deprivation confirms the diagnosis.

choices.text: Marked villous scalloping is seen on histopathology
Bilateral enlarged ovaries will be seen

questions.text: A 21-year-old primigravida presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of mild vaginal bleeding for the past two weeks. She has no fetal movements, and her last menstrual period (LMP) was three months ago. On examination, her uterus is larger than gestational age, and serum β-hCG is markedly elevated (>1,000,000 mIU/mL). Ultrasound (USG) reveals a characteristic "snowstorm appearance" with no identifiable fetus. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The likely karyotype is 69XXY

 

  • The ultrasound findings of a "snowstorm appearance" with no fetus are diagnostic of a complete molar pregnancy (hydatidiform mole).
  • Complete moles have a karyotype of 46XX or 46XY, not 69XXY, making option A incorrect.
  • They result from fertilization of an empty ovum by a sperm that undergoes duplication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marked villous scalloping seen on HPE: Incorrect for complete mole, but true for partial mole. Complete moles show diffuse hydropic swelling of villi, but no scalloping.

 

Option C. Bilateral enlarged ovaries seen: Correct – Theca-lutein cysts develop due to excess β-hCG stimulation, causing bilateral ovarian enlargement.

 

Option D. Absent fetal erythrocytes: Correct – Complete moles have no fetal tissue, no fetal erythrocytes, and no fetal vasculature.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
A 21-year-old woman presents with pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath for the past 2 hours. She has smoked 20 cigarettes a day for 7 years. On examination, she has decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance to percussion on her right chest.

 

Investigation:

 

CXR: 

 

 

What’s the likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pneumothorax

 

  • The patient's presentation of pleuritic chest pain, shortness of breath, decreased breath sounds, and hyperresonance to percussion is strongly suggestive of a pneumothorax. 
  • A pneumothorax occurs when air enters the pleural space, leading to a collapsed lung. This results in decreased breath sounds on auscultation and hyperresonance to percussion due to the trapped air. 
  • On CXR, the classic finding in pneumothorax is the absence of lung markings in the affected area, as the lung has collapsed and the air-filled pleural space is visible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD): COPD presents with chronic cough, dyspnoea, and wheezing, especially in smokers, but it would not cause the acute symptoms of pleuritic chest pain and the findings of hyperresonance to percussion or absence of lung markings on CXR.

 

Option B. Lung cancer: Lung cancer can cause chronic cough, weight loss, and pleuritic chest pain, but it typically does not present with an acute pneumothorax as the initial symptom, and the CXR would usually show a mass rather than the absence of lung markings.

 

Option C. Obstructive sleep apnoea: Obstructive sleep apnoea presents with daytime fatigue, loud snoring, and episodes of breath cessation during sleep, but it would not cause pleuritic chest pain or shortness of breath with hyperresonance on examination.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Pneumothorax should be suspected in a patient with acute pleuritic chest pain, dyspnoea, and physical exam findings of decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance to percussion. The absence of lung markings on CXR is the classic finding confirming the diagnosis of pneumothorax.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of progressive nail changes over the past few months. Which condition is this nail abnormality most characteristic of?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lichen planus

 

  • Pterygium formation of the nail is a classic feature of lichen planus, an inflammatory disease affecting the skin, hair, nails, and mucous membranes.
  • In lichen planus, the proximal nail fold advances over the nail bed, leading to scarring and destruction of the nail matrix, resulting in the distinctive pterygium deformity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Psoriasis:

 

  • Psoriasis causes nail changes such as pitting, onycholysis, and subungual hyperkeratosis.
  • However, pterygium formation is not characteristic of psoriasis.

 

Option C. Tinea Unguium (Onychomycosis):

 

  • A fungal infection of the nails causing discoloration, thickening, and onycholysis.
  • It does not lead to pterygium formation.

 

Option D. Alopecia Areata:

 

  • Alopecia areata can cause nail changes such as pitting and trachyonychia (rough, ridged nails).
  • However, it does not cause pterygium.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Pterygium formation (proximal nail fold adhesion to the nail bed) is a hallmark of lichen planus, distinguishing it from psoriasis, fungal infections, and alopecia areata.

questions.text: What is the minimum and maximum scoring given in Ballard score?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) -10 & 50

 

  • The Ballard Score is a gestational age assessment tool used in neonates. It evaluates neuromuscular and physical maturity characteristics of newborns to estimate their gestational age, particularly when there is uncertainty about the last menstrual period (LMP) or when there is suspected prematurity. The minimum possible score is -10, which corresponds to 22 weeks of gestation, while the maximum possible score is 50, which correlates with 44 weeks of gestation.

 

Ballard Score Components:

 

The Ballard Score consists of two major domains:

 

  1. Neuromuscular Maturity
    • Posture
    • Square window (wrist flexion)
    • Arm recoil
    • Popliteal angle
    • Scarf sign
    • Heel-to-ear maneuver
  2. Physical Maturity
    • Skin
    • Lanugo
    • Plantar surface creases
    • Breast tissue
    • Eye/Ear development
    • Genitalia (male & female)

 

Each criterion is scored between -1 to 5, giving a total score range from -10 (extremely preterm, ~22 weeks) to 50 (post-term, ~44 weeks).

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • The Ballard Score is an essential tool in neonatology to estimate gestational age, particularly for preterm or growth-restricted neonates. 
  • It helps in planning medical management, predicting complications, and guiding interventions for premature infants.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by his family with complaints of difficulty understanding spoken language for the past few days. The patient appears fluent in speech, but his words are nonsensical and lack meaning. He is unaware of his speech impairment. On neurological examination, he is unable to follow simple verbal commands but can execute written commands. His repetition is impaired. Which of the following brain regions is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superior temporal gyrus

 

  • This patient presents with Wernicke’s aphasia, which is characterized by:
    • Fluent speech with no meaningful content (word salad).
    • Impaired comprehension of spoken language.
    • Poor repetition.
    • Lack of awareness of the deficit (anosognosia).
  • Wernicke’s area (Brodmann area 22) is located in the superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere (usually left) and is responsible for language comprehension.
  • Infarcts affecting this area are often due to an occlusion of the middle cerebral artery (MCA), particularly the inferior division.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inferior frontal gyrus:

 

  • Houses Broca’s area (Brodmann areas 44, 45), responsible for speech production.
  • Lesions cause Broca’s aphasia, where the patient has non-fluent, effortful speech but preserved comprehension.

 

Option C. Angular gyrus:

 

  • Located in the parietal lobe and involved in reading and writing.
  • Lesions cause alexia (inability to read) and agraphia (inability to write).

 

Option D. Postcentral gyrus:

 

  • Contains the primary somatosensory cortex (Brodmann areas 3, 1, 2).
  • Lesions cause contralateral sensory deficits rather than language impairment.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Broca's motor speech area - (44,45) is located in the inferior frontal gyrus.
  • Wernicke's area - (22) is located in the superior temporal gyrus.

questions.text: A 36-year-old sexually active male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of left testicular pain that started 24 hours ago. He denies any recent trauma or urinary symptoms. On examination, his scrotum is swollen, erythematous, and tender. Elevation of the testis lowers the pain.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epididymo-orchitis

 

  • Sexually active male is likely to get affected by STDs leading to acute epididymo-orchitis
  • Positive Prehn’s sign: Pain reduces upon testicular elevation (helping differentiate from torsion)
  • Swelling and erythema of the scrotum due to inflammation

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Testicular torsion: 

 

  • Seen in teenagers
  • Negative Prehn’s sign: Pain worsens upon lifting the testis.

 

Option C. Inguinal hernia with testicular involvement:

 

  • Would present with a non-reducible groin swelling extending into the scrotum.

 

Option D. Fournier’s gangrene:

 

  • A necrotizing soft tissue infection affecting the perineum and scrotum.
  • Typically seen in diabetic or immunocompromised patients.
  • Associated with severe systemic symptoms (fever, hypotension, crepitus) which are absent in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 15-year-old old girl is brought to the OPD by her concerned mother. Her mother tells you that the patient has not yet attained menarche. She is performing well in school and takes part in several sports activities. On examination, you note that the breast and pubic hair are Tanner stage 1. Her height is appropriate. On evaluation, her FSH and LH are low. What could be a possible cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Physiological delay

 

  • This patient has primary amenorrhea with absent secondary sexual characteristics (Tanner Stage 1 breasts & pubic hair).
  • Low FSH and LH indicate hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, suggesting an issue with the hypothalamic-pituitary axis rather than the ovaries.
  • Physiological delay is the most common cause of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, often seen in adolescents who are high-achievers or engage in intense physical activity.

 

Causes of Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism (Low FSH, LH):

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pure Gonadal Dysgenesis - 46XX or Turner Syndrome - 45XO: Incorrect because gonadal dysgenesis is associated with high FSH & LH due to ovarian failure (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism).

 

Option C. Swyer Syndrome - 46XY Complete Gonadal Dysgenesis: Incorrect because patients with Swyer syndrome have streak gonads, leading to high FSH & LH levels (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism).

 

Option D. Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome - 46XY: Incorrect because AIS presents with normal breast development (due to estrogen conversion), absent uterus, and absent pubic hair. FSH & LH levels are normal or high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological delay is the most common cause of primary amenorrhea with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, especially in adolescents who are high achievers or active in sports.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding body fluid compartments is/are correct?

 

  1. Intracellular fluid makes up 40% of body weight.
  2. Interstitial fluid accounts for 15% of body weight.
  3. Plasma contributes to 10% of body weight.
  4. Total body water is approximately 60% of body weight.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 4

 

Statement 1. Intracellular fluid is 40% of body weight.

 

Statement 2. Interstitial fluid is 15% of body weight.

 

Statement 4. Total body water is about 60% of body weight.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 3. Plasma volume is only 5% (not 10%).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The body fluid compartments are divided into intracellular (40%) and extracellular (20%), which includes interstitial fluid (15%) and plasma (5%).

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back for 2 hours. She is diaphoretic, with epigastric tenderness and guarding.

 

Investigations reveal:

 

  • Serum amylase: 1300 U/L (normal range: 60-180)
  • CT image is shown below 

 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute pancreatitis

 

  • This patient’s presentation of sudden, severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, sweating (diaphoresis), epigastric tenderness, and abdominal guarding suggests acute pancreatitis. 
  • The significant elevation in serum amylase (1300 U/L, which is markedly higher than the normal range of 60-180 U/L) is also highly indicative of acute pancreatitis.
  • Acute pancreatitis occurs due to autodigestion of pancreatic tissue by the pancreatic enzymes, leading to necrosis and inflammation. 
  • The most common causes of acute pancreatitis are gallstones and alcohol use. 
  • Other causes can be summarized by the acronym GET SMASHED (Gallstones, Ethanol, Trauma, Steroids, Mumps, Autoimmune, Scorpion stings, Hypercalcemia, ERCP, Drugs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute cholecystitis: While acute cholecystitis also presents with epigastric pain, it is typically associated with right upper quadrant tenderness, not the radiating back pain seen in acute pancreatitis. Additionally, serum amylase would typically be normal or mildly elevated in acute cholecystitis, unlike in acute pancreatitis.

 

Option C. Aortic dissection: Aortic dissection often presents with tearing chest pain that radiates to the back and is usually associated with hypertension or a history of vascular disease. While epigastric pain can occur, the characteristic elevated amylase and absence of aortic murmur or signs of aortic rupture make this diagnosis less likely in this patient.

 

Option D. Ascending cholangitis: Ascending cholangitis typically presents with fever, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice (Charcot's triad). It is usually associated with elevated liver enzymes, not a marked elevation in amylase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute pancreatitis is characterized by severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, abdominal tenderness, and guarding, with a significant elevation in serum amylase. 
  • The most common causes include gallstones and alcohol use. Early diagnosis and supportive treatment are essential to manage acute pancreatitis, as it can lead to severe complications like necrosis, infection, and systemic inflammation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with complaints of rectal bleeding and a sensation of tissue prolapse during defecation. He reports that the prolapsed tissue spontaneously retracts after bowel movements. Based on this description, what is the most appropriate classification of his hemorrhoids and their management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Second-degree hemorrhoids, Sclerotherapy

 

  • Second-degree hemorrhoids are characterized by prolapse during defecation but spontaneous reduction without manual assistance. 
  • The patient’s symptoms of rectal bleeding and tissue prolapse that retracts spontaneously match this classification. 
  • They are usually managed by minimally invasive procedures like sclerotherapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Second-degree hemorrhoids, Milligan Morgan procedure: Second-degree hemorrhoids are usually managed by minimally invasive procedures like sclerotherapy or banding. Open hemorrhoidectomy of Milligan Morgan is usually reserved for grade 3 or grade 4.

 

Option C and D. Third-degree hemorrhoids:

 

  • Hemorrhoids prolapse but require manual reduction.
  • This is not the case here, as the patient’s prolapse resolves spontaneously.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding Hemorrhoid Grading and Classification

choices.text: Toluidine blue, malachite green, glacial acetic acid
Carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, and methylene blue

questions.text: A patient presents with a thick, grayish pseudomembrane covering the throat and tonsils, along with fever, chills, and swollen cervical glands for a week. A Gram-positive organism is identified in a nasopharyngeal swab using a special stain. Which of the following staining methods is used to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Toluidine blue, malachite green, glacial acetic acid

 

  • The thick, gray pseudomembrane in the throat suggests a Corynebacterium diphtheriae infection (diphtheria). 
  • The special stain used for Corynebacterium diphtheriae is the Albert’s stain, which contains Toluidine blue, malachite green and glacial acetic acid. 
  • This stain highlights the metachromatic granules (Babes-Ernst granules/volutin granules) seen in diphtheria bacilli, which appear bluish-green with dark blue granules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crystal violet, Gram’s iodine: Used in Gram staining, which can identify Corynebacterium diphtheriae as a Gram-positive rod, but does not highlight metachromatic granules.

 

Option C. Carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, and methylene blue: Used in Ziehl-Neelsen staining (Acid-fast stain), which is specific for Mycobacteria and Nocardia.

 

Option D. Methylene Blue: Can be used for simple staining but does not differentiate Babes-Ernst granules, making it less specific than Albert’s stain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Albert’s stain (Toluidine blue, malachite green, glacial acetic acid) is used for Corynebacterium diphtheriae to detect metachromatic Babes-Ernst granules.
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae is a Gram-positive, club-shaped bacillus that forms pseudomembranes in the throat, leading to airway obstruction and systemic toxin effects.
  • Diphtheria toxin inhibits EF-2, blocking protein synthesis and causing systemic complications (myocarditis, neuropathy).
  • Vaccination with DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus) is the best preventive measure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a wellness consultation. She has a family history of obesity and metabolic syndrome and wants to maintain a healthy BMI of 24 kg/m². Her height is 1.68 meters. Based on this BMI goal, what should be her ideal weight range in kilograms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 63-68 kg

 

  • The body mass index (BMI) is a widely used measure of body fat and is calculated using the formula:

 

 

To determine the ideal weight range for a BMI of 24 kg/m², we rearrange the formula:

 

Weight = BMI × Height2

 

Substituting the given values:

 

Weight = 24 × (1.68×1.68) = 24 x 2.8 ≈ 67.2 kg

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The ideal weight for a given BMI can be calculated using the formula: Weight = BMI × (Height)².

questions.text: Identify the instrument
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nasopharyngeal airway

 

  • Description: The nasopharyngeal airway (also known as a nasal trumpet) is a soft, flexible tube inserted through the nostril to maintain a patent airway. It is used in patients who are semi-conscious or have a gag reflex, where an oropharyngeal airway would not be suitable.
  • Usage: It is often used in situations where the patient cannot tolerate an oropharyngeal airway, such as in cases of oral trauma or during seizure activity.
  • Why This: The nasopharyngeal airway is designed to be inserted through the nose, which matches the design seen in the image provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oropharyngeal Airway:

 

  • Description: An oropharyngeal airway is a curved, rigid plastic device inserted into the mouth to prevent the tongue from obstructing the airway. It is commonly used in unconscious patients who have no gag reflex. It helps maintain a patent airway in situations where the tongue could obstruct breathing.
  • Usage: Typically used in emergency settings to keep the airway open in unconscious patients.
  • Why Not This: The oropharyngeal airway is inserted through the mouth, not the nose, and it is more rigid compared to the nasopharyngeal airway.

 

 

Option B. Ovassapian Airway

 

  • Description: The Ovassapian airway is a specialized airway used to facilitate fiberoptic intubation, particularly in patients who have difficult airways. It is designed to keep the airway open while allowing the passage of a fiberoptic scope.
  • Usage: Primarily used in anesthesia and in cases of difficult airway management for fiberoptic intubation.
  • Why Not This: The Ovassapian airway has a different shape and design meant specifically for intubation procedures, and it is not typically used as a general airway management tool like the nasopharyngeal airway.

 

 

Option D. Uncuffed Endotracheal Tube

 

  • Description: An uncuffed endotracheal tube is a flexible plastic tube inserted into the trachea to maintain an open airway or deliver oxygen directly to the lungs. The uncuffed version is often used in pediatric patients or short-term procedures.
  • Usage: Used primarily in surgical settings or in critically ill patients who require mechanical ventilation.
  • Why Not This: The uncuffed endotracheal tube is a straight tube without the flared end seen in the image. It also does not feature the curved, softer design of the nasopharyngeal airway.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The nasopharyngeal airway (nasal trumpet) is a flexible tube designed to be inserted through the nostril to maintain airway patency, especially in patients who cannot tolerate an oropharyngeal airway. 
  • It is most suitable for semi-conscious patients or those with intact gag reflexes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with difficulty breathing and stridor following a severe allergic reaction. Examination reveals edema at the laryngeal inlet, partially obstructing airflow. Which of the following muscles is responsible for opening the inlet of the larynx?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroepiglottic

 

  • The thyroepiglottic muscle is responsible for opening the laryngeal inlet, ensuring proper airflow into the airway.
  • It is an intrinsic muscle of the larynx, derived from the thyroarytenoid muscle, and functions by pulling the epiglottis anteriorly, widening the laryngeal inlet.
  • This action is important during breathing to ensure an open airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyrohyoid: Elevates the larynx and hyoid bone, but does not open the inlet.

 

Option C. Sternothyroid: Depresses the larynx, helping in low-pitch sound modulation, but has no role in opening the inlet.

 

Option D. Aryepiglottic: Closes the laryngeal inlet (opposite function of the thyroepiglottic muscle) by pulling the epiglottis downward, preventing aspiration during swallowing.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with progressive blurry vision and difficulty driving at night is diagnosed with age-related cataracts. He is scheduled for phacoemulsification with intraocular lens implantation. Which of the following is the correct sequence of surgical steps in phacoemulsification? 

 

  1. Hydrodissection
  2. Nuclear fragmentation
  3. Implantation of IOL
  4. Staining of Anterior capsule of lens
  5. Continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4, 5, 1, 2, 3

 

Phacoemulsification follows a stepwise approach:

 

4. Staining of the anterior capsule (using Trypan blue) is done first, particularly in dense cataracts, to improve visualization.

 

5. Continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis (CCC) is performed to create an opening in the anterior lens capsule.

 

1. Hydrodissection separates the nucleus from the cortex, facilitating its removal.

 

2. Nuclear fragmentation is done using an ultrasound probe to emulsify the nucleus.

 

3. Implantation of intraocular lens (IOL) completes the procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Phacoemulsification follows a precise surgical sequence for successful cataract removal: capsule staining, capsulorhexis, hydrodissection, nuclear fragmentation, and IOL implantation. 
  • Staining improves visualization in mature cataracts.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents symptoms given in the picture below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Behçet’s Syndrome

 

  • Behçet’s syndrome is a chronic, relapsing vasculitis that classically presents with a triad of:
  • Recurrent oral ulcers
  • Genital ulcers
  • Ocular involvement (uveitis or retinal vasculitis)
  • Additional findings include erythema nodosum-like lesions, thrombosis, arthritis, and neurological involvement. The pathergy test (skin hyper-reactivity) is often positive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reiter’s Syndrome (Reactive Arthritis):

 

  • Triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis/uveitis ("Can't see, can't pee, can't climb a tree").
  • Often follows a Chlamydia or enteric infection.
  • Does not typically present with painful oral and genital ulcers.

 

Option C. Stevens-Johnson Syndrome:

 

  • Severe mucocutaneous reaction due to drugs or infections.
  • Widespread skin detachment, bullae, and involvement of multiple mucosal sites.
  • Does not have recurrent flares like Behçet’s syndrome.

 

Option D. Pemphigus Vulgaris:

 

  • Autoimmune blistering disorder with flaccid bullae and erosions.
  • Oral ulcers occur, but genital ulcers and uveitis are not characteristic.
  • Positive Nikolsky’s sign (skin shearing with slight pressure).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Behçet’s syndrome is a systemic vasculitis characterized by recurrent painful oral ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis, with a positive pathergy test.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF) is given medications to prevent a premature luteinizing hormone (LH) surge, which could lead to premature ovulation and cycle cancellation. The physician prescribes a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist as part of the protocol. Which of the following medications is used to prevent the premature LH surge during IVF?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leuprolide acetate

 

  • During IVF, it is crucial to prevent a premature LH surge, which could lead to premature ovulation and loss of viable oocytes.
  • Leuprolide acetate (GnRH agonist) initially stimulates, then suppresses pituitary LH and FSH secretion via downregulation of GnRH receptors, preventing the surge.
  • In women at risk of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS), leuprolide acetate can also be used as the ovulation trigger instead of hCG.

 

Methods to Prevent Premature LH Surge in IVF:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recombinant LH: Incorrect – Recombinant LH is used to support follicular development, not to prevent an LH surge.

 

Option B. Recombinant FSH: Incorrect – Recombinant FSH is used to stimulate follicle growth, not to regulate LH levels.

 

Option D. Human Menopausal Gonadotropin - hMG: Incorrect – hMG contains both FSH and LH and is used to stimulate follicle growth, not to suppress LH.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Adipocere, due to anaerobic conditions created by the sealed bag.
Mummification, due to evaporation within a confined environment.
Putrefaction, accelerated by the marsh environment.
Fermentation, due to microbial activity within the sealed environment.

questions.text: A forensic team recovers a body from a sealed plastic bag found submerged in a marsh. The body exhibits a waxy, white appearance with preserved soft tissues but emits a foul odor. Which post-mortem change has most likely occurred, and what factor primarily contributed to its preservation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adipocere, due to anaerobic conditions created by the sealed bag.

 

  • Adipocere formation is likely in this scenario due to the anaerobic, moist conditions facilitated by the sealed plastic bag in a marshy area. 
  • This environment supports the hydrolysis and hydrogenation of body fats, leading to the waxy preservation of the body, despite the presence of a foul odor typical of anaerobic bacterial activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mummification, due to evaporation within a confined environment: Mummification is unlikely as it requires dry conditions to promote evaporation, not present in a sealed, moist environment.

 

Option C. Putrefaction, accelerated by the marsh environment: Putrefaction is possible but would not explain the waxy, preserved state of soft tissues.

 

Option D. Fermentation, due to microbial activity within the sealed environment: Fermentation could contribute to the odor but would not result in waxy tissue preservation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Adipocere and Mummification:

questions.text: Match the following cellular structures with their corresponding functions:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-3, B-1, C-4, D-2

 

  • A-3: Tight Junctions are made up of claudin and occludin, regulating paracellular permeability.
  • B-1: Gap Junctions contain connexons, allowing communication in cardiac and smooth muscle cells.
  • C-4: Adherens Junctions anchor cells together using cadherin and catenin.
  • D-2: Desmosomes provide mechanical strength and support.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Tight junctions regulate permeability, gap junctions facilitate intercellular communication, adherens junctions anchor cells, and desmosomes provide structural support.

questions.text: An x-ray of the pelvis was taken evaluating a patient with patellar instability. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fong’s disease

 

  • This is a rare genetic disorder affecting the development of nails, kneecaps, kidneys, and other bones.
  • A hallmark feature is patellar hypoplasia or dysplasia, which predisposes to patellar instability.
  • Pelvic X-rays reveal characteristic iliac horns, which are bony projections on the iliac bones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Achondroplasia: This is the most common form of dwarfism, caused by a mutation in the FGFR3 gene. It primarily affects bone growth, leading to shortened limbs, particularly the proximal segments (rhizomelic shortening). Pelvic X-rays in achondroplasia typically show characteristic features, such as a small, squared iliac wing and a narrow pelvic outlet. While there can be skeletal abnormalities, patellar instability is not a primary characteristic of achondroplasia.

 

Option B. Diaphyseal aclasis (Multiple hereditary exostoses): This is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple bony outgrowths (exostoses) on the surfaces of bones, particularly near the growth plates. These exostoses can cause deformities, pain, and limited joint movement. Pelvic involvement can occur, with exostoses arising from the iliac bones. While knee issues can arise from this condition, it is not a primary cause of Patellar instability.

 

Option D. Metaphyseal dysplasia: This is a group of disorders that affect the metaphyses of long bones. These disorders can cause various skeletal abnormalities, including short stature, limb deformities, and joint problems. While some forms of metaphyseal dysplasia may involve the knees, it is not as strongly associated with patellar instability as Nail-patella syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The association between pelvic X-ray findings and patellar instability, Fong's disease (Nail-patella syndrome) is the most probable diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman presents with confusion, difficulty finding words, and weakness in her right arm and leg. She has a history of hypertension managed with amlodipine.

 

Examination Findings:

 

  • Speech: Fluent, but with unrelated words and sentences lacking meaning (suggestive of Wernicke’s aphasia)
  • Motor deficit: Right-sided weakness and sensory loss

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Partial Anterior Circulation Infarct (PACI)

 

  • This patient exhibits features of an anterior circulation stroke affecting the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory:
    1. Higher cerebral dysfunction (Wernicke’s aphasia) – Fluent but nonsensical speech with impaired comprehension, suggesting a lesion in the left superior temporal gyrus (dominant hemisphere).
    2. Right-sided hemiparesis and sensory loss – Suggests involvement of the left MCA territory, which supplies the motor and sensory cortices.
  • This fits Partial Anterior Circulation Stroke (PACI) in the Bamford classification, which includes:
    • Unilateral weakness and/or sensory loss (face, arm, and/or leg)
    • Higher cerebral dysfunction (e.g., aphasia, visuospatial deficits)
    • Possible homonymous hemianopia (not present here)

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Lacunar infarct: Typically causes pure motor or pure sensory stroke, without cortical signs (e.g., aphasia, neglect).

 

Option B. Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome): Causes ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome, dysphagia, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature, not aphasia or hemiparesis.

 

Option D. Posterior circulation infarct: Would cause vertigo, ataxia, cranial nerve deficits, and homonymous hemianopia, but not aphasia or hemiparesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Partial anterior circulation infarcts (PACI) occur in the MCA or ACA territory and present with hemiparesis, sensory deficits, and higher cerebral dysfunction (e.g., aphasia, visuospatial neglect). 
  • Wernicke’s aphasia (fluent but nonsensical speech) localizes the lesion to the dominant (left) superior temporal gyrus.

questions.text: A senior surgeon delegates a crucial part of a surgical procedure to a junior surgeon without proper oversight. The junior surgeon makes a critical mistake leading to significant patient harm. Under which doctrine is the senior surgeon also likely to be held accountable for the junior surgeon's actions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vicarious liability

 

  • Vicarious liability holds individuals or entities responsible for the actions of others under their supervision. 
  • In this medical scenario, the senior surgeon can be held liable for the junior surgeon's mistake due to the principle of Respondeat Superior, which is part of vicarious liability, emphasizing the senior's oversight responsibility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corporate negligence: Corporate negligence pertains to institutional errors, not directly related here.

 

Option C. Doctrine of product liability: Doctrine of product liability deals with manufacturers' responsibility for defective products, not applicable.

 

Option D. Novus actus interveniens: Novus actus interveniens refers to an intervening event that disrupts the chain of causation, not the case here.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Summary of medico-legal doctrines:

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a thyroid nodule, and FNAC results are inconclusive due to insufficient cellularity. Which of the following factors is most likely responsible for the inadequate sample?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystic degeneration of the nodule

 

  • Cystic thyroid nodules often yield inadequate FNAC samples due to a paucity of follicular cells.
  • The fluid component may be aspirated, but the solid component may contain too few cells for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased vascularity of the lesion: Incorrect. Can cause bloody aspirates but does not usually affect cellular adequacy.

 

Option C. Hyperfunctioning thyroid nodule: Incorrect. "Hot" nodules are rarely malignant but usually yield sufficient cells.

 

Option D. Hashimoto’s thyroiditis: Incorrect. Lymphocytic infiltration can make diagnosis difficult but usually does not cause inadequate sampling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cystic thyroid nodules often result in inadequate FNAC samples due to low cellularity.

choices.text: Attached to the inner border of the 2nd rib
Covers the apical part of the lung
Part of the scalenus minimus muscle

questions.text: A 35-year-old construction worker presents with pain and swelling in the lower neck following a fall from a height. He reports difficulty breathing, and on examination, there is reduced air entry over the right lung apex. A CT scan reveals herniation of the cervical pleura into the lower neck, suggesting an injury to a fascial structure that protects the lung apex and separates the neck from the thoracic cavity. Which of the following statements regarding this fascial structure is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Attached to the inner border of the 2nd rib

 

  • Sibson’s fascia (suprapleural membrane) is a fibrous layer covering the apex of the lung, separating the lower neck from the thoracic cavity.
  • It is attached to the inner border of the 1st rib, not the 2nd rib, making option A incorrect.
  • It reinforces the thoracic inlet, preventing lung herniation into the neck and stabilizing intrathoracic pressure changes.
  • It receives muscular fibers from the scalenus minimus muscle, strengthening its structure.
  • The subclavian vessels pass above it, ensuring protection for the subclavian artery and vein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Covers apical part of lung: Correct – Sibson’s fascia covers the lung apex, preventing injury from neck movements.

 

Option C. Part of scalenus minimus muscle: Correct – Some fibers of scalenus minimus reinforce the suprapleural membrane.

 

Option D. Vessels pass above the fascia: Correct – The subclavian artery and vein lie above Sibson’s fascia, protecting them from lung expansion forces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Sibson’s fascia / suprapleural membrane's function is to protect the apex of the lung (the part that extends outside the rib cage) and the cervical fascia. This aids in resisting intrathoracic pressure changes, preventing neck inflation and deflation during expiration and inspiration, and also providing rigidity to the thoracic inlet.
  • Herniation of the cervical fascia may result due to injury to suprapleural membrane.

choices.text: It is classified as a psychotic disorder in DSM-5
Antipsychotic medications are always necessary for treatment
It is considered a Cluster A personality disorder
It typically has a late onset in adulthood

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with a long-standing pattern of social and interpersonal deficits, cognitive or perceptual distortions, and eccentricities of behavior. He reports magical thinking and odd beliefs. Which of the following statements about his condition is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is considered a Cluster A personality disorder

 

  • The patient exhibits social and interpersonal deficits, cognitive or perceptual distortions, eccentric behavior, magical thinking, and odd beliefs, which are characteristic of schizotypal personality disorder (STPD). 
  • This disorder is classified under Cluster A personality disorders in the DSM-5, along with paranoid and schizoid personality disorders. 
  • Individuals with STPD often have unusual beliefs, suspiciousness, and social anxiety but do not have frank psychosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is classified as a psychotic disorder in DSM-5: Schizotypal personality disorder is not a psychotic disorder but a personality disorder. While it shares features with schizophrenia, such as perceptual distortions and odd thinking, it lacks persistent delusions or hallucinations.

 

Option B. Antipsychotic medications are always necessary for treatment: Antipsychotics may be used if transient psychotic symptoms occur, but they are not always necessary. Psychotherapy (especially social skills training) is the mainstay of treatment.

 

Option D. It typically has a late onset in adulthood: Personality disorders, including schizotypal personality disorder, typically begin in adolescence or early adulthood, not late adulthood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Schizotypal personality disorder (STPD) is a Cluster A personality disorder characterized by eccentric behavior, social deficits, perceptual distortions, and magical thinking. 
  • It is distinct from schizophrenia as it does not involve persistent psychotic symptoms. 
  • Treatment primarily involves psychotherapy, with medications reserved for symptom management when necessary.

choices.text: Loss of sequences on the short arm of chromosome 3

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with hematuria, flank pain, and an unintentional 15-lb weight loss over the past 3 months. A CT scan reveals a solid hypervascular mass in the upper pole of the left kidney. Histopathology demonstrates polygonal cells with abundant clear cytoplasm. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most strongly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loss of sequences on the short arm of chromosome 3

 

  • Clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) is strongly associated with the loss of the VHL gene on chromosome 3p.
  • This gene encodes the von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) protein, which regulates hypoxia-inducible factors (HIF).
  • Loss of VHL leads to upregulation of angiogenic factors (VEGF, PDGF), resulting in hypervascular tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BRAF V600E mutation: Incorrect. Associated with melanoma and hairy cell leukemia, not ccRCC.

 

Option B. t(14;18) translocation: Incorrect. Seen in follicular lymphoma, not renal cancer.

 

Option D. JAK2 V617F mutation: Incorrect. Seen in myeloproliferative disorders, not ccRCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clear cell renal cell carcinoma is associated with VHL gene inactivation due to loss of chromosome 3p sequences, leading to increased angiogenesis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the clinic with hypertension, palpitations, and episodic headaches. Laboratory findings reveal elevated plasma metanephrines, and an abdominal CT scan identifies an adrenal mass, raising suspicion for pheochromocytoma. The physician explains that the excessive catecholamine synthesis in this tumor involves a key rate-limiting enzymatic step in norepinephrine production. Which of the following reactions represents the rate-limiting step in norepinephrine synthesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conversion of tyrosine to DOPA

 

  • The rate-limiting step in norepinephrine (NE) synthesis is the conversion of tyrosine to DOPA, which is catalyzed by the enzyme tyrosine hydroxylase. 
  • This step is crucial because it is highly regulated and subject to negative feedback inhibition by norepinephrine.

 

The full catecholamine synthesis pathway is as follows:

 

 

  • Since tyrosine hydroxylase activity determines the overall rate of catecholamine synthesis, it is considered the rate-limiting enzyme in this pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine: Catalyzed by phenylalanine hydroxylase, but this is not the rate-limiting step in norepinephrine synthesis. It is a precursor step in phenylketonuria (PKU) but does not regulate catecholamine synthesis.

 

Option C. Conversion of DOPA to dopamine: Mediated by DOPA decarboxylase, but this step is not the rate-limiting step and proceeds rapidly once DOPA is available.

 

Option D. Conversion of dopamine to norepinephrine: Catalyzed by dopamine β-hydroxylase, but this is not the rate-limiting step and occurs efficiently in norepinephrine-secreting neurons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The rate-limiting step in norepinephrine synthesis is the conversion of tyrosine to DOPA, catalyzed by tyrosine hydroxylase. 
  • This step is regulated by negative feedback from norepinephrine and determines overall catecholamine production.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding dehydration in infants are true?

 

  1. Decreased urine output is a hallmark feature of dehydration.
  2. Sunken eyeballs are seen in moderate to severe dehydration.
  3. Peri-anal excoriation is a common sign of dehydration in infants.
  4. Severe dehydration can cause lethargy or an unconscious state.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4

 

Statement 1. Decreased urine output is a hallmark feature of dehydration: Decreased urine output is a hallmark feature of dehydration due to reduced renal perfusion and decreased fluid volume.

 

Statement 2. Sunken eyeballs are seen in moderate to severe dehydration: Sunken eyeballs are commonly seen in moderate to severe dehydration, indicating fluid loss from interstitial spaces.

 

Statement 4. Severe dehydration can cause lethargy or an unconscious state: Severe dehydration can lead to lethargy, unconsciousness, or floppiness, indicating circulatory collapse and inadequate cerebral perfusion.

 

Other Option:
