Statement 3. Peri-anal excoriation is a common sign of dehydration in infants: Peri-anal excoriation is not a sign of dehydration; it is associated with lactose intolerance due to acidic stools causing skin irritation.

 

WHO Classification of Dehydration in Infants

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: There is abnormal umbilical artery Doppler

questions.text: A 38-week primigravida presents with decreased fetal movements. A modified biophysical profile (mBPP) is performed, and the non-stress test (NST) is reactive. The second component of the test, as shown in the ultrasound images, involves measuring the amniotic fluid index (AFI). What is your inference?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) There is oligohydramnios

 

  • Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) is measured by summing the vertical pockets of amniotic fluid in the four quadrants of the uterus on ultrasound.

 

AFI Interpretation:

 

  • Normal: 5-25 cm
  • Oligohydramnios: AFI < 5 cm
  • Polyhydramnios: AFI > 25 cm

 

In this case, AFI = 0 + 1.2 + 1.6 + 2.2 = 4.9 cm, which is oligohydramnios.

 

Oligohydramnios is an indication for delivery in a term pregnancy, as it suggests uteroplacental insufficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is normal: Incorrect. AFI of less than 5 cm is considered oligohydramnios.

 

Option C. There is fetal hypoxia: Incorrect. Oligohydramnios itself does not confirm hypoxia. A reactive NST suggests adequate fetal oxygenation.

 

Option D. There is abnormal umbilical artery Doppler: Incorrect. Umbilical artery Doppler is not assessed in a modified BPP. While oligohydramnios can be associated with abnormal Doppler findings, it is not diagnostic of abnormal umbilical artery flow.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Deposition of immune complexes in glomeruli
Direct invasion of red blood cells by Plasmodium falciparum

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman presents with fatigue, bruising, and confusion. Physical examination reveals petechiae and mild jaundice. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

  • Hemoglobin: 7.0 g/dL
  • Platelets: 15,000/μL
  • Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH): Elevated
  • Haptoglobin: Undetectable
  • Peripheral smear: 

 

 

What is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autoantibodies targeting ADAMTS13

 

  • The presence of schistocytes on the peripheral smear, thrombocytopenia, and hemolytic anemia suggest thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). 
  • TTP is caused by autoantibodies against ADAMTS13, a protease responsible for cleaving von Willebrand factor. 
  • Without ADAMTS13, large von Willebrand factor multimers promote platelet aggregation and microvascular thrombosis, leading to hemolysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Deposition of immune complexes in glomeruli: This describes immune-complex-mediated glomerulonephritis, which does not cause microangiopathic hemolysis.

 

Option C. Bone marrow suppression by chemotherapy: This causes pancytopenia but does not explain the schistocytes or hemolysis.

 

Option D. Direct invasion of red blood cells by Plasmodium falciparum: Malaria can cause hemolysis but typically presents with parasitized red cells, not schistocytes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • TTP is caused by autoantibodies against ADAMTS13, leading to microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and schistocytes.

choices.text: Ability to establish a temporal relationship between exposure and outcome
Ability to use retrospective data for quick analysis

questions.text: A large study investigates the relationship between air pollution exposure and cardiovascular disease by following 50,000 individuals over 15 years and periodically recording their air pollution exposure and health status. Which of the following key strengths best differentiates this study design from a case-control study?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ability to establish a temporal relationship between exposure and outcome

 

  • Cohort studies track participants over time, allowing researchers to observe exposure before disease onset, making them the best for establishing temporal relationships.
  • In contrast, case-control studies are retrospective, meaning exposure data is collected after disease onset, making it harder to prove causation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ability to determine multiple exposures: Case-control studies are better suited for studying multiple exposures because they collect detailed past histories from cases.

 

Option C. Efficiency in studying rare diseases: Case-control studies are superior for rare diseases because cohort studies require large sample sizes and long follow-up times.

 

Option D. Ability to use retrospective data for quick analysis: Case-control studies, not cohort studies, allow quick retrospective data collection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cohort studies are superior to case-control studies in establishing a temporal relationship between exposure and outcome, making them more reliable for causal inference.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with fever, lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly. Blood smear reveals characteristic cells, as shown in the image below. Which of the following is a potential complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Splenic rupture

 

  • Splenic rupture is a known complication of infectious mononucleosis caused by EBV. 
  • Splenomegaly increases the risk of rupture, particularly with trauma or physical exertion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bone marrow failure: Not a common complication of infectious mononucleosis.

 

Option C. Acute kidney injury: Rarely associated with EBV infection.

 

Option D. Hemolytic anemia: Can occur in EBV infections but is less common than splenic rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Splenic rupture is a potentially life-threatening complication of infectious mononucleosis, especially in patients with significant splenomegaly.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with open-angle glaucoma is prescribed latanoprost. During a follow-up visit, he expresses concern about changes in the color of his iris and longer eyelashes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Latanoprost

 

  • Latanoprost is a prostaglandin F2-alpha (PGF2α) analog used in the treatment of open-angle glaucoma. 
  • It lowers intraocular pressure by increasing uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor.

 

Notable ocular side effects of latanoprost include:

 

  • Heterochromia iridis (permanent darkening of the iris)
  • Increased eyelash growth (hypertrichosis)
  • Cystoid macular edema (in susceptible individuals, e.g., post-cataract surgery patients)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brimonidine: An alpha-2 agonist, can cause CNS depression and apnea in newborns, but not iris pigmentation.

 

Option C. Pilocarpine: A miotic agent that can cause cataracts and stenosis of the nasolacrimal system, but not iris color changes.

 

Option D. Timolol: A beta-blocker used for glaucoma, which does not affect iris pigmentation or eyelash growth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Latanoprost (PGF2α analog) is associated with heterochromia iridis (iris darkening), eyelash growth, and cystoid macular edema.

 

Ocular adverse effects of anti-glaucoma drugs

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain and repeated vomiting following a night of excessive alcohol consumption and a heavy meal. He also complains of difficulty breathing and left-sided chest discomfort. On examination, his vitals show tachycardia. Chest X-ray reveals left-sided pleural effusion with possible mediastinal widening. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CECT Thorax + Abdomen

 

  • The clinical presentation strongly suggests Boerhaave’s syndrome (spontaneous esophageal perforation), a life-threatening condition caused by forceful retching leading to esophageal rupture. 
  • This results in mediastinitis and pleural effusion due to gastric content leakage.

 

Key features suggestive of Boerhaave’s syndrome:

 

  • History of forceful vomiting after alcohol binge
  • Severe retrosternal chest pain (due to esophageal rupture)
  • Left-sided pleural effusion (seen on imaging)
  • Risk of mediastinitis and sepsis if untreated

 

Why CECT Thorax + Abdomen?

 

  • Gold standard imaging for suspected esophageal perforation
  • Detects site of perforation, pleural effusion, pneumomediastinum, and mediastinitis
  • Confirms diagnosis before intervention

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diagnostic Laparoscopy:

 

  • Not the first-line diagnostic tool for esophageal perforation
  • Invasive and not required unless surgical exploration is planned

 

Option B. USG Thorax:

 

  • Can detect pleural effusion but cannot identify esophageal perforation
  • Lacks sensitivity for mediastinal or esophageal pathology

 

Option D. Upper GI Endoscopy

 

  • Contraindicated in suspected Boerhaave’s syndrome as it may worsen the perforation
  • May increase esophageal pressure, further damaging the perforated site

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with complaints of urinary retention following a cesarean section. She is started on a cholinergic agonist that acts selectively on muscarinic receptors without affecting the neuromuscular junction. Which of the following drugs was most likely administered?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bethanechol

 

  • The question subtly describes a scenario of postoperative urinary retention while hiding the specific drug name. 
  • It also forces the examinee to recognize that the drug must be muscarinic-specific, eliminating acetylcholinesterase inhibitors like physostigmine and neostigmine, which also affect nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neostigmine: Increases acetylcholine (Ach) at both muscarinic and nicotinic receptors, making it unsuitable for purely muscarinic effects.

 

Option B. Pyridostigmine: Primarily used in myasthenia gravis, acting on nicotinic receptors.

 

Option C. Physostigmine: Crosses the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and is used in atropine toxicity, but it does not selectively target muscarinic receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bethanechol is a direct muscarinic agonist used for postoperative ileus and urinary retention, as it does not affect nicotinic receptors.
